levels.title: Level 1: Greetings
levels.description: Learn the specific greetings for Morning, Afternoon, and Evening (Ẹ káàárọ̀, Ẹ káàsán, Ẹ káalẹ́). Cultural focus: Why you must greet before asking for anything.
learningObjectives: Greet appropriately at different times of day
Understand the cultural importance of greetings in Yoruba culture

vocabulary.example: Ẹ káàárọ̀, báwo ni?
vocabulary.culturalNote: Used from morning until around noon. Always greet elders first.

vocabulary.example: Ẹ káàsán, ńkọ́ ilé?
vocabulary.culturalNote: Used from noon until late afternoon.

vocabulary.example: Ẹ káalẹ́, ẹ kú iṣẹ́?
Báwo ni? – Dáadáa ni, ẹ ṣé.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Informal; for peers or younger people.

vocabulary.example: Dáadáa ni, ẹ ṣé.
Ẹ ṣé púpọ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Polite form; use for elders or multiple people.

vocabulary.example: Kò tọ́pẹ́, ẹ máa bọ̀.
Ẹ kú iṣẹ́, ó ṣe é.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Used to greet someone who has been working.

vocabulary.example: Ẹ kú ojúmọ́, ẹ jí?
Ó dàbọ̀, ó máa bọ̀.

grammarPoints.explanation: Yoruba has emphatic pronouns used for clarity or emphasis. They are: Èmi (I), Ìwọ (you), Òun (he/she), Àwa (we), Ẹ̀yin (you pl.), Àwọn (they).
examples: Èmi ni mo wá – It is I who came.
Ìwọ lọ – You go.

grammarPoints.explanation: Greetings often start with 'Ẹ' (plural/polite) or 'O' (singular informal). The verb 'kú' is used with a noun describing the time or activity.
examples: Ẹ kú iṣẹ́ – Greetings on your work.
O kú ojúmọ́ – Good morning (to a friend).

dialogue.speaker: Bàbá (Elder)
dialogue.text: Ẹ káàárọ̀, ọmọ mi.
dialogue.translation: Good morning, my child.

dialogue.speaker: Ọmọ (Child)
dialogue.text: Ẹ káàárọ̀, bàbá. Ẹ kú iṣẹ́?
dialogue.translation: Good morning, father. Well done on your work?

dialogue.speaker: Bàbá
dialogue.text: Dáadáa ni, ọmọ mi. Báwo ni ilé?
dialogue.translation: I'm fine, my child. How is home?

dialogue.speaker: Ọmọ
dialogue.text: Ilé wà dáadáa. Ẹ ṣé.
dialogue.translation: Home is fine. Thank you.

culturalNotes.title: The Importance of Greetings
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba culture, greetings are not just formalities; they show respect, acknowledge hierarchy, and establish connection. Failing to greet an elder is considered very rude.

culturalNotes.title: Prostrating and Kneeling
culturalNotes.content: Younger people often prostrate (for males) or kneel (for females) when greeting elders, especially parents or chiefs. This physical gesture accompanies the verbal greeting.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Good morning' in Yoruba?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ káàárọ̀' is the correct greeting for morning.

practiceExercises.question: What is the appropriate response to 'Báwo ni?'
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Dáadáa ni' means 'I am fine'.

practiceExercises.question: Which greeting would you use for someone who has just finished working?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ kú iṣẹ́' is used to acknowledge someone's work.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ó dàbọ̀' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ó dàbọ̀' is used when parting.

practiceExercises.question: Which pronoun is the polite/plural form of 'you'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ̀yin' is the plural/polite 'you'.

tips: Use these greetings with your children every morning to build habit.
Drop a 'Báwo ni?' in your DMs – it's a cool way to check in with friends.
Start meetings with 'Ẹ káàárọ̀' to show cultural respect to Nigerian clients.
Practice kneeling/prostrating when greeting your partner's parents – it shows deep respect.
In Lagos, you'll hear these greetings everywhere – master them to blend in.
Practice greetings out loud every day.
Observe the time of day when using greetings.
When in doubt, use 'Ẹ' (polite) instead of 'O'.

levels.title: Level 2: Common Expressions
levels.description: Learn how to ask about well‑being, say 'Hello', 'How are you?', 'Where are you from?', and 'What is your name?'.
learningObjectives: Ask and answer simple personal questions
Use common expressions in daily conversation

vocabulary.example: Ṣé dáadáa ni? – Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, mo dúpẹ́.
Kí nìdí? Nítorí pé mo fẹ́ kọ́.
Kí lórúkọ rẹ? – Orúkọ mi ni Adé.
Orúkọ mi ni Adé.
Níbòó lò ńgbé? – Mo ńgbé ní Ìbàdàn.
Mo ńgbé ní Èkó.
Báwo lọ́rẹ ń ṣe? – Ó wà dáadáa.
Ó wà dáadáa, ẹ ṣé.
Ẹ jọ̀wọ́, ẹ sọ fún mi.
Kí ló ń ṣẹlẹ̀? – Kò sí nkankan.

grammarPoints.explanation: In Yoruba, yes/no questions are often formed by starting with 'Ṣé' (like 'is it that...') and then the statement.
examples: Ṣé ó wà nílé? – Is he at home?
Ṣé o lọ sí ọjà? – Did you go to the market?

grammarPoints.explanation: Possessive pronouns come after the noun: 'orúkọ mi' (my name), 'ilé rẹ' (your house), 'bàbá wa' (our father).
examples: Orúkọ mi ni Túndé.
Ilé wọn tóbi.
grammarPoints.pattern: Noun + pronoun (mi, rẹ, rẹ̀, wa, yín, wọn)

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Báwo ni, Bolú? Ṣé dáadáa ni?
dialogue.translation: How are you, Bolu? Are you well?

dialogue.speaker: Bolú
dialogue.text: Mo wà dáadáa, ẹ ṣé. Ìwọ ńkọ́?
dialogue.translation: I am fine, thank you. And you?

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Dáadáa ni. Kí lórúkọ ọ̀rẹ́ rẹ?
dialogue.translation: Fine. What is your friend's name?

dialogue.speaker: Bolú
dialogue.text: Orúkọ rẹ̀ ni Kúnlé. Ó ńgbé ní Ìbàdàn.
dialogue.translation: His name is Kunle. He lives in Ibadan.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Kí ló ń ṣe níbẹ̀?
dialogue.translation: What does he do there?

dialogue.speaker: Bolú
dialogue.text: Ó jẹ́ olùkọ́.
dialogue.translation: He is a teacher.

culturalNotes.title: Respect in Addressing Others
culturalNotes.content: Yoruba people often use titles or kinship terms (e.g., Ẹ̀gbọ́n – elder sibling) rather than first names when addressing someone older. It's a sign of respect.

culturalNotes.title: Asking About Family
culturalNotes.content: It's common to ask about someone's family after greetings – 'Báwo ni àwọn ọmọ?' (How are the children?). This shows genuine interest.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'What is your name?' informally?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kí lórúkọ rẹ?' is the informal way to ask someone's name.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ṣé dáadáa ni?' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ṣé dáadáa ni?' asks about someone's well-being.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I live in Lagos'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo ńgbé ní Èkó' correctly states 'I live in Lagos'.

practiceExercises.question: Which phrase means 'What's happening?'
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kí ló ń ṣẹlẹ̀?' is a casual way to ask what's going on.

practiceExercises.question: What is the possessive pronoun for 'my' in Yoruba?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'mi' means 'my' as in 'orúkọ mi' – my name.

tips: Ask your children 'Kí lórúkọ ọ̀rẹ́ rẹ?' to encourage them to introduce friends.
Use 'Kí ló ń ṣẹlẹ̀?' when sliding into DMs – it's smooth.
In networking, start with 'Orúkọ mi ni ...' and ask 'Níbòó lò ńgbé?' to build rapport.
Practice asking your in-laws about their well‑being with 'Báwo ni?' – it's essential.
When meeting someone new in Nigeria, these questions will help you connect.
Use 'Ẹ jọ̀wọ́' frequently to sound polite.
Listen for the tone – Yoruba is tonal, so practice pronunciation.
Combine these expressions with greetings from Level 1.

levels.title: Level 3: Introducing Yourself
levels.description: Learn to introduce yourself: name, origin, occupation, and family background.
learningObjectives: Introduce yourself with name and origin
Talk about your occupation or study

vocabulary.example: Mo wá láti Ìpínlẹ̀ Ọ̀yọ́.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Used to state your hometown or state.

vocabulary.example: Ilú mi ni Ìbàdàn.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Often used with 'inú' (inside) to mean hometown.

vocabulary.example: Kí ni iṣẹ́ rẹ? – Iṣẹ́ mi ni agbẹ̀.
Bàbá mi jẹ́ agbẹ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Many Yoruba families have farming background.

vocabulary.example: Mo jẹ́ ọmọ ilé ìwé.
Ó jẹ́ olùkọ́ nínú ilé ìwé.
Mo jẹ́ oníṣòwò ní ọjà.
Bàbá mi ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní ìlú.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Also used as a respectful title for older men.

vocabulary.example: Ìyá mi jẹ́ oníṣòwò.
Ẹbí mi tóbi.

grammarPoints.explanation: In Yoruba, 'jẹ́' is used to equate nouns, similar to 'is/are' for professions, identities. It is often omitted in simple statements but used for emphasis or in certain constructions.
examples: Mo jẹ́ olùkọ́ – I am a teacher.
Adé jẹ́ ọmọ ilé ìwé – Ade is a student.

grammarPoints.explanation: To say you come from a place, use 'Mo wá láti' (I come from) followed by the place name.
examples: Mo wá láti Ìbàdàn.
Ó wá láti Ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Ẹ káàsán. Orúkọ mi ni Bísí. Ìwọ ńkọ́?
dialogue.translation: Good afternoon. My name is Bisi. And you?

dialogue.speaker: Táyé
dialogue.text: Orúkọ mi ni Táyé. Mo wá láti Ìbàdàn. Ìwọ wá láti ibo?
dialogue.translation: My name is Taye. I come from Ibadan. Where do you come from?

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Mo wá láti Èkó. Kí ni iṣẹ́ rẹ?
dialogue.translation: I come from Lagos. What is your occupation?

dialogue.speaker: Táyé
dialogue.text: Mo jẹ́ olùkọ́. Ìwọ ẹ?
dialogue.translation: I am a teacher. And you?

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Mo jẹ́ oníṣòwò. Ẹbí mi wà ní Èkó.
dialogue.translation: I am a businessperson. My family is in Lagos.

culturalNotes.title: Introducing Family First
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba culture, when meeting someone new, it's common to mention your family background – who your parents are, where they come from – as it establishes social connections.

culturalNotes.title: Praise Names (Oríkì)
culturalNotes.content: Many Yoruba people have praise poetry (oríkì) associated with their lineage. After introducing your name, elders might recite your oríkì to honor your ancestry.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I am a student'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọmọ ilé ìwé' means student.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Mo wá láti' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo wá láti' expresses origin.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'What is your occupation?'
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kí ni iṣẹ́ rẹ?' directly asks for occupation.

practiceExercises.question: Which word means 'family'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹbí' is the word for family.

practiceExercises.question: What is the Yoruba word for 'teacher'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Olùkọ́' means teacher.

tips: Teach your children to introduce themselves with both names and hometown.
In your bio, you can put 'Mo wá láti ...' to show your roots.
When networking, introduce your profession confidently with 'Mo jẹ́ ...'.
Practice introducing your own family to your partner's family.
If you move to a new city, saying where you come from helps people place you.
Remember that 'jẹ́' is often dropped in casual speech: 'Mo olùkọ́'.
When stating your hometown, use 'ní' before the place: 'Mo ńgbé ní ...' for residence, 'Mo wá láti ...' for origin.

levels.title: Level 4: Empathy
levels.description: Learn the non‑apology 'Sorry' (Má bínú, Ẹ mà bínú) and differentiate from asking for forgiveness.

vocabulary.example: Má bínú, mo gbàgbé.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Used when you've annoyed someone; it's a plea not to be angry.

vocabulary.example: Ẹ mà bínú, mo pé.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Polite form for elders or multiple people.

vocabulary.example: Mo tọrọ àforíjì fún ẹ.
vocabulary.culturalNote: More formal apology, often used in serious matters.

vocabulary.example: Kò burú, má ṣàníyàn.
Ó dára, mo gbà.
Ẹ kú ìnú rere lórí ẹni tó ṣaláìsí.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Used at funerals, literally 'greetings of good heart' – a condolence.

vocabulary.example: Ẹ máa gbàdúrà, Ọlọ́run ó gbọ́.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Often said to someone going through hardship.

vocabulary.example: Kò sí wahala, mo lóye.
Ó ṣàdédé, má bínú.

vocabulary.translation: I beg your pardon / excuse me
vocabulary.example: Mo tọrọ àyè, mo fẹ́ kọjá.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Asking permission to pass or interrupt.

grammarPoints.explanation: To form a negative command, use 'má' before the verb. For polite/plural, add 'ẹ'.
examples: Má bínú – Don't be angry.
Ẹ má ṣàníyàn – Don't worry (pl.).

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Mo tọrọ' means 'I beg for' and is used with nouns like 'àforíjì' (forgiveness) or 'àyè' (space/permission).
examples: Mo tọrọ àforíjì – I beg forgiveness.
Mo tọrọ àyè – Excuse me.

dialogue.speaker: Kúnlé
dialogue.text: Má bínú, mo tẹ̀ ẹ́ mọ́lẹ̀ láìmọ̀.
dialogue.translation: Sorry, I stepped on it unknowingly.

dialogue.speaker: Bólá
dialogue.text: Kò burú, ó ṣàdédé.
dialogue.translation: It's okay, it was an accident.

dialogue.speaker: Kúnlé
dialogue.text: Ẹ mà bínú fún pípé.
dialogue.translation: Sorry for being late.

dialogue.speaker: Bólá
dialogue.text: Ó dára, wọlé.
dialogue.translation: It's fine, come in.

dialogue.speaker: Kúnlé
dialogue.text: Mo tọrọ àforíjì fún gbogbo rẹ̀.
dialogue.translation: I beg forgiveness for everything.

dialogue.speaker: Bólá
dialogue.text: Kò sí wahala, a dúpẹ́.
dialogue.translation: No trouble, we are grateful.

culturalNotes.title: The Non‑Apology 'Sorry'
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba, 'Má bínú' is often used not to admit fault, but to soothe the other person's anger. It's a social lubricant, not necessarily an admission of guilt.

culturalNotes.title: Condolences
culturalNotes.content: At funerals, one says 'Ẹ kú ìnú rere' or 'Ẹ kú ọ̀fọ̀'. It's important to visit the bereaved and sit with them in silence as much as speaking.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Sorry (don't be angry)' informally?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Má bínú' is the informal way to say sorry.

practiceExercises.question: What is the response to an apology meaning 'It's okay'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kò burú' is a common acceptance of apology.

practiceExercises.question: How do you offer condolences for a death?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ kú ìnú rere' is used for condolences.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Mo tọrọ àyè' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo tọrọ àyè' is asking for space/permission.

practiceExercises.question: Which phrase means 'No trouble'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kò sí wahala' literally 'there is no trouble'.

tips: Teach children to say 'Má bínú' when they make mistakes – it teaches emotional intelligence.
When you accidentally offend a friend, a quick 'Má bínú' goes a long way.
In business, a polite 'Ẹ mà bínú' for a small delay shows respect.
In‑laws appreciate a sincere 'Mo tọrọ àforíjì' if you ever cause offense.
If you step on someone's foot in a bus, 'Má bínú' is the expected response.
Tone matters: 'Má bínú' said with a smile softens the apology.
When in doubt, use the polite 'Ẹ' version.

levels.title: Level 5: Basic Needs
levels.description: Learn to ask for basic necessities: water, food, restroom, and help.
learningObjectives: Ask for water, food, and directions to facilities

vocabulary.example: Mo fẹ́ omi mu.
Mo fẹ́ oúnjẹ jẹ.
Ilé ìgbọ̀nsẹ̀ wà níbo?
Mo fẹ́ ìrànlọ́wọ́ rẹ.
Mo fẹ́ omi.
Jọ̀wọ́, fún mi ní omi.
Fún mi ní oúnjẹ.
Kò sí omi níbí.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Common response when something is unavailable.

vocabulary.example: Omi wà níbí.
Ṣé o gbọ́? – Mo gbọ́.

grammarPoints.explanation: The verb 'fẹ́' means 'want' or 'desire'. It's followed by a noun or a verb phrase with 'láti' (to).
examples: Mo fẹ́ omi – I want water.
Mo fẹ́ láti jẹun – I want to eat.

grammarPoints.explanation: To ask 'where is ...?' use 'Níbo ni ... wà?'.
examples: Níbo ni ilé ìgbọ̀nsẹ̀ wà? – Where is the toilet?
Níbo ni ọjà wà? – Where is the market?

dialogue.speaker: Àdùké
dialogue.text: Jọ̀wọ́, mo fẹ́ omi mu.
dialogue.translation: Please, I want to drink water.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Omi wà nínú àpótí. Kí ló tún ṣe?
dialogue.translation: Water is in the container. Anything else?

dialogue.speaker: Àdùké
dialogue.text: Níbo ni ilé ìgbọ̀nsẹ̀ wà?
dialogue.translation: Where is the restroom?

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Ó wà lẹ́yìn ilé.
dialogue.translation: It is behind the house.

dialogue.speaker: Àdùké
dialogue.text: Mo dúpẹ́. Mo fẹ́ ìrànlọ́wọ́ pẹ̀lú.
dialogue.translation: Thank you. I also want help.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Kò sí wahala. Kí ni?
dialogue.translation: No problem. What is it?

culturalNotes.title: Hospitality
culturalNotes.content: Yoruba people are known for hospitality. If you ask for water, you'll likely be given some even if it's the last they have.

culturalNotes.title: Refusing Help
culturalNotes.content: It's polite to refuse help initially ('Kò burú, mo lè ṣe é') but accept if insisted – it's part of the culture of communal support.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I want water'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo fẹ́ omi' is the correct phrase.

practiceExercises.question: What is the word for 'restroom'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ilé ìgbọ̀nsẹ̀' means toilet.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'Where is the toilet?'
practiceExercises.explanation: That's the correct phrasing.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Fún mi ní omi' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Fún mi ní omi' is a direct request: 'Give me water'.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Please' in Yoruba?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Jọ̀wọ́' is the word for please.

tips: Teach kids to use 'Jọ̀wọ́' and 'Mo fẹ́' to express needs politely.
When out with friends, you can say 'Mo fẹ́ omi' – it's casual.
In an office, 'Mo fẹ́ ìrànlọ́wọ́ rẹ' is a polite way to ask a colleague for help.
Asking your spouse for something with 'Jọ̀wọ́, fún mi ní ...' keeps interactions respectful.
If you're lost, ask 'Níbo ni ... wà?' – people are usually happy to help.
Always use 'Jọ̀wọ́' when making a request.
Listen for 'Kò sí' – it means it's not available, so you may need to look elsewhere.

levels.title: Level 6: Food
levels.description: Ordering street food: Yam and Egg, Boli, Suya. Key phrases: 'I want small small,' 'Add pepper,' 'Pack for me take away.'

vocabulary.example: Mo fẹ́ bọ̀lì méjì.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Popular street food, often eaten with groundnut.

vocabulary.example: Sùyà pẹ̀lú ata.
Ẹ̀ja kíkún kan, jọ̀wọ́.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Often served with garri or bread.

vocabulary.example: Mo fẹ́ ẹ̀ko.
Fún mi ní ata.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Nigerians love pepper – ask for 'díẹ̀' (small) if you can't handle much.

vocabulary.example: Fún mi ní díẹ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Useful when you want just a little.

vocabulary.example: Ẹ fi ata pọ̀ sí i.
Ẹ fi ẹ̀ja sí i.
Ẹ fi gbé, màá jẹ nílé.
Mo fẹ́ jẹun.

grammarPoints.explanation: Counting is essential for ordering. 1: ọ̀kan, 2: méjì, 3: mẹ́ta, 4: mẹ́rin, 5: àrún, 6: mẹ́fà, 7: méje, 8: mẹ́jọ, 9: mẹ́sàn-án, 10: mẹ́wàá.
examples: Mo fẹ́ bọ̀lì mẹ́ta – I want three boli.
Sùyà méjì – Two suya.
grammarPoints.pattern: Noun + number (without prefix for counting objects)

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'Ẹ fi X sí i' to ask to add X to the order.
examples: Ẹ fi ata sí i – Add pepper.
Ẹ fi ẹ̀ja sí i – Add fish.

dialogue.speaker: Oníbàárà (Customer)
dialogue.text: Ẹ kú iṣẹ́. Mo fẹ́ bọ̀lì mẹ́rin.
dialogue.translation: Well done. I want four boli.

dialogue.speaker: Olùtajà (Seller)
dialogue.text: Ó dára. Ẹ fẹ́ fi ata sí i?
dialogue.translation: Okay. Do you want to add pepper?

dialogue.speaker: Oníbàárà
dialogue.text: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, ẹ fi díẹ̀ sí i. Ẹ̀wo ló wà?
dialogue.translation: Yes, add a little. How much is it?

dialogue.speaker: Olùtajà
dialogue.text: Ọ́ọ́ń ṣe márùn-ún. Ẹ fẹ́ sùyà pẹ̀lú?
dialogue.translation: It's five hundred. Do you want suya too?

dialogue.speaker: Oníbàárà
dialogue.text: Rárá o, bọ̀lì nìkan. Ẹ fi gbé.
dialogue.translation: No, just boli. Pack it for takeaway.

dialogue.speaker: Olùtajà
dialogue.text: Kò burú. Ẹ jọ̀wọ́ ẹ dúró díẹ̀.
dialogue.translation: Okay. Please wait a little.

culturalNotes.title: Street Food Etiquette
culturalNotes.content: In Nigeria, it's common to eat with your hands from shared plates. Always wash your hands before eating. If offered food, it's polite to accept a little, even if you're not hungry.

culturalNotes.title: Haggling at Food Stalls
culturalNotes.content: Prices are often negotiable, especially for larger quantities. A friendly 'Ẹ jọ̀wọ́, ẹ dín kù' (please reduce it) can work.

practiceExercises.question: How do you order two suya?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'méjì' means two.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ẹ fi ata sí i' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ fi ata sí i' means 'add pepper'.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'pack it for takeaway'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ fi gbé' is the phrase for takeaway.

practiceExercises.question: What is 'bọ̀lì'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Bọ̀lì' is roasted plantain.

practiceExercises.question: If you want a small amount of pepper, you say:
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Díẹ̀' means a little.

tips: Take your children to a suya spot and practice ordering in Yoruba – they'll love it.
When you go out with friends, show off by ordering in Yoruba – it's a vibe.
If you're taking a client to a local eatery, knowing food terms shows cultural fluency.
Ask your spouse how they like their suya – it's a fun way to bond.
If you're new to Nigeria, start with 'díẹ̀' pepper and work your way up!
Numbers are key – practice counting 1-10.
When ordering takeaway, say 'Ẹ fi gbé' clearly.
If you don't want pepper, say 'Má fi ata sí i' (don't add pepper).

levels.title: Level 7: Directions
levels.description: Asking for directions: 'Where is...' and understanding 'Straight,' 'Turn at the big mango tree,' 'It is facing the road.'

vocabulary.example: Níbo ni ilé oúnjẹ wà?
Lọ síwájú títí o fi dé ọ̀nà.
Yí sí apá òtún ní igi ọ̀pẹ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Literally 'turn to the right hand side'.

vocabulary.example: Yí sí apá òsì ní ọjà.
Ó wà nítòsí ilé ìwé.
Ó jìnnà sí ibí díẹ̀.
Ó wà lẹ́yìn ilé.
Ó wà níwájú mọ́kà.
Yí sí apá òtún ní igi ọ̀pẹ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: In rural areas, trees are used as landmarks.

vocabulary.example: Ó wà lójú òpópónà.

grammarPoints.explanation: Give directions using the base form of the verb (without a subject). 'Lọ' (go), 'yí' (turn), 'dúró' (stop).
examples: Lọ síwájú – Go straight.
Yí sí apá òtún – Turn right.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'ní' to mean 'at' or 'in' a place.
examples: Ó wà ní ọjà – It is at the market.
Mo ńgbé ní Ìbàdàn – I live in Ibadan.

dialogue.speaker: Arìnrìn-àjò (Traveler)
dialogue.text: Ẹ jọ̀wọ́, níbo ni ilé oúnjẹ tó súnmọ́ tó wà?
dialogue.translation: Please, where is the nearest restaurant?

dialogue.speaker: Ará ìlú (Local)
dialogue.text: Lọ síwájú títí o fi dé igi ọ̀pẹ̀ ńlá. Lẹ́yìn náà, yí sí apá òsì.
dialogue.translation: Go straight until you reach a big palm tree. Then turn left.

dialogue.speaker: Arìnrìn-àjò
dialogue.text: Ṣé ó wà nítòsí ibẹ̀?
dialogue.translation: Is it near there?

dialogue.speaker: Ará ìlú
dialogue.text: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, ó wà ní apá òsì rẹ, lójú òpópónà.
dialogue.translation: Yes, it's on your left, facing the road.

dialogue.speaker: Arìnrìn-àjò
dialogue.text: Mo dúpẹ́ púpọ̀.
dialogue.translation: Thank you very much.

culturalNotes.title: Landmarks Over Street Names
culturalNotes.content: In many Nigerian cities, street names are less known than landmarks: a particular shop, a big tree, a mosque. Directions often rely on these.

culturalNotes.title: Helping Strangers
culturalNotes.content: Yoruba people are generally helpful to strangers. If you look lost, someone may approach and ask 'Níbo lò ńlọ?' (Where are you going?).

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'Where is the restaurant?'
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ilé oúnjẹ' means restaurant.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'yí sí apá òtún' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Apá òtún' is right side.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Go straight'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Lọ síwájú' means go forward.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'nítòsí' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Nítòsí' indicates proximity.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Yí sí apá òsì', you should:
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Apá òsì' is left.

tips: When driving with kids, practice giving directions in Yoruba – it makes it fun.
Use these phrases when giving friends directions to your house.
If you're meeting a client at an unfamiliar location, confirm the landmarks with these phrases.
Ask your spouse's family for directions to their village – they'll be impressed.
Learn to recognize common landmarks like 'igi ọ̀pẹ̀' (palm tree) – they're everywhere.
When receiving directions, repeat them back to confirm.
If you're lost, don't be afraid to ask again – people understand.

levels.title: Level 8: Haggling
levels.description: Market negotiations: 'Reduce it for me,' 'Last price?' 'Na you be the boss,' 'How much?'
learningObjectives: Ask for the price of items

vocabulary.example: Èló ni bọ̀lì yìí?
vocabulary.culturalNote: The most common question in markets.

vocabulary.example: Jọ̀wọ́, ẹ dín kù díẹ̀.
Ó pọ̀ jù, ẹ dín kù.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Expressing that the price is high.

vocabulary.example: Ẹ dín kù ìdíẹ̀.
Kí ni iye tó kẹ́yìn?
vocabulary.culturalNote: Asking for the final, non‑negotiable price.

vocabulary.example: Mo gbà, mo máa rà á.
vocabulary.culturalNote: When you agree on a price.

vocabulary.example: Kò ṣeé ṣe, ó kéré jù.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Seller might say this if your offer is too low.

vocabulary.example: Ẹ jọ̀wọ́, ẹ dín kù.

vocabulary.translation: You are the boss (Na you be the boss)
vocabulary.example: Ìwọ ló ń ṣe bába, ẹ fún mi lóore.
Mo máa ronú, mo tún wá.

grammarPoints.explanation: To ask 'how many?' use 'Mélòó?'.
examples: Mélòó ni o fẹ́? – How many do you want?
Bọ̀lì mélòó? – How many boli?

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'jẹ́ kí' to say 'let's' or 'let me'.
examples: Jẹ́ kí n rí i – Let me see it.
Jẹ́ ká ṣe àdéhùn – Let's make a deal.

dialogue.speaker: Oníbàárà (Customer)
dialogue.text: Èló ni bàtà yìí?
dialogue.translation: How much are these shoes?

dialogue.speaker: Olùtajà (Seller)
dialogue.text: Ó ń ṣe ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́wàá naira.
dialogue.translation: It's ten thousand naira.

dialogue.speaker: Oníbàárà
dialogue.text: Ó pọ̀ jù! Ẹ jọ̀wọ́, ẹ dín kù.
dialogue.translation: That's too much! Please reduce it.

dialogue.speaker: Olùtajà
dialogue.text: Kò ṣeé ṣe. Ẹ̀wẹ́, ó dára púpọ̀.
dialogue.translation: It's not possible. Besides, it's very good quality.

dialogue.speaker: Oníbàárà
dialogue.text: Mo fún yín ní ẹgbẹ̀rún méjìdínlógún. Ìwọ ló ń ṣe bába!
dialogue.translation: I'll give you eight thousand. You are the boss!

dialogue.speaker: Olùtajà
dialogue.text: Ó dára, mo gbà. Kí ni o tún fẹ́?
dialogue.translation: Okay, I accept. What else do you want?

culturalNotes.title: Haggling is Expected
culturalNotes.content: In Nigerian markets, the first price is never the final price. Haggling is a social dance, and both parties expect it. Smile and be friendly.

culturalNotes.title: Flattery Works
culturalNotes.content: Complimenting the seller or their goods – 'ó dára gan' (it's very beautiful) – can soften them for a better price.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'How much?' in Yoruba?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Èló?' is the direct question for price.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'dín kù' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Dín kù' means reduce (the price).

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'last price'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Iye tó kẹ́yìn' is the final price.

practiceExercises.question: If a seller says 'Kò ṣeé ṣe', what do they mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kò ṣeé ṣe' means it's not possible / can't be done.

practiceExercises.question: Which phrase is flattering the seller?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ìwọ ló ń ṣe bába' means 'You are the boss'.

tips: Take your children to the market and let them practice haggling – it's a life skill.
Haggling is a game – use 'Ìwọ ló ń ṣe bába' with a smile and you'll get better prices.
Even if you're buying in bulk, polite haggling is expected. Use these phrases.
If you go to the market with your spouse, let them do the haggling – or practice together.
If you're new, watch locals haggle first. Then try with small items.
Start with a lower offer than you expect to pay.
Be prepared to walk away – often the seller will call you back.
Always smile – haggling is friendly, not aggressive.

levels.title: Level 9: Exiting
levels.description: Polite disengagement: 'I am in a hurry,' 'Let me go small,' 'I will come back.'
learningObjectives: Explain you are in a hurry

vocabulary.example: Mo kánjú, mo máa lọ.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Useful when you need to leave quickly.

vocabulary.translation: Let me go small / I'll step out briefly
vocabulary.example: Jẹ́ ki n lọ díẹ̀, màá padà wá.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Casual way to say you're leaving for a bit.

vocabulary.example: Màá padà wá ní ọ̀sán.
Ó dàbọ̀, ó máa bọ̀.
Ó máa bọ̀, ẹ rora.
Ẹ rora, kí Ọlọ́run bà yín.

vocabulary.translation: Goodbye / Amen (used as farewell in some contexts)
vocabulary.example: Àṣẹ́ o, a ó tún pàdé.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Common among Christians as a blessing.

vocabulary.example: Kí ni ó dùn tó o fi ń lọ?
vocabulary.culturalNote: Someone might ask why you're leaving.

vocabulary.example: Mo lọ nítorí àìsàn.
vocabulary.culturalNote: If you need to leave due to illness.

vocabulary.example: Mo lọ, Ọlọ́run á san mí.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Often said when leaving a gathering.

grammarPoints.explanation: To express a future action, use 'máa' before the verb.
examples: Màá lọ – I will go.
Màá padà wá – I will come back.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'nítorí' to give a reason.
examples: Mo lọ nítorí iṣẹ́ – I left because of work.
Ó lọ nítorí àìsàn – He left due to sickness.

dialogue.speaker: Túnjí
dialogue.text: Ẹ jọ̀wọ́, mo kánjú. Mo máa lọ nísisìyí.
dialogue.translation: Please, I am in a hurry. I will go now.

dialogue.speaker: Gbẹ̀nga
dialogue.text: Kí ló ṣẹlẹ̀? Kí ni ó dùn?
dialogue.translation: What happened? What's wrong?

dialogue.speaker: Túnjí
dialogue.text: Mo ní ìpàdé kan. Màá padà wá lọ́la.
dialogue.translation: I have a meeting. I will come back tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: Gbẹ̀nga
dialogue.text: Ó dàbọ̀, ẹ rora lọ.
dialogue.translation: Goodbye, go safely.

dialogue.speaker: Túnjí
dialogue.text: Ó dàbọ̀, ó máa bọ̀.
dialogue.translation: Goodbye, see you later.

culturalNotes.title: Prolonged Farewells
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba culture, leaving a gathering often involves multiple rounds of goodbyes. It's polite to explain why you're leaving and to assure you'll return.

culturalNotes.title: Blessings When Departing
culturalNotes.content: When someone leaves, it's common to say 'Ọlọ́run á máa bà ọ' (God be with you) or 'Ẹ rora' (take care).

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I am in a hurry'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo kánjú' means I am in a hurry.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Màá padà wá' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Màá padà wá' means I will return.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'goodbye' (as the leaver)?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ó dàbọ̀' is said by the person leaving.

practiceExercises.question: What is the response to 'Ó dàbọ̀'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ó máa bọ̀' means 'come again'.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'take care'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ rora' is 'take care'.

tips: Teach children to say 'Màá padà wá' when they go out to play – it reassures you.
When leaving a party, a quick 'Mo kánjú, ó dàbọ̀' is polite and cool.
In a business meeting, 'Mo kánjú, mo ní ìpàdé míì' (I have another meeting) is acceptable.
When leaving your in‑laws' house, always say 'Màá padà wá' – they like to know you'll visit again.
If you need to leave a social event, explain briefly – people will understand.
Always give a reason when leaving – it's considered polite.
If you're not sure when you'll return, say 'Màá padà wá nígbà tí ó bá ṣeé ṣe' (I'll come back when possible).

practiceExercises.question: The neighbour mentions their child is sick. You want to express sympathy. What do you say?

practiceExercises.question: You realize you've been talking loudly and apologize. How do you say 'sorry'?

practiceExercises.question: The neighbour accepts your apology. What might they say?

levels.title: Level 11: Home
levels.description: Vocabulary for the Nigerian household: Verandah, Parlour, 'Go and bring the kettle.'
learningObjectives: Identify common rooms and items in a Nigerian home
Give and understand simple commands at home

vocabulary.example: Ilé mi wà ní Èkó.
vocabulary.culturalNote: The concept of home extends to the entire compound, often including extended family.

vocabulary.example: Ẹ jọ́kòó sí pàràńgà ká tùtù.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Verandahs are common gathering spots for relaxation in the evening.

vocabulary.example: Àwọn àlejò wà ní pálọ́ọ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: The parlour is where guests are received; often furnished with upholstered sets.

vocabulary.example: Ìyá ń ṣe oúnjẹ nínú ìdáná.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Traditionally separate from the main house, but modern homes have attached kitchens.

vocabulary.example: Yàrá ìsùn mi wà ní òkè.
Lọ mú kẹ́túlù wá, a máa mu tíì.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Borrowed from English; used for boiling water for tea or instant coffee.

vocabulary.example: Jọ́kòó sórí àga.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Traditional stools (àpò) are also used, but 'àga' is general.

vocabulary.example: Oúnjẹ wà lórí tábìlì.
Ṣí fèrèsé kí atẹ́gùn wọlé.
vocabulary.culturalNote: In older homes, windows are louvres; in modern, sliding glass.

vocabulary.example: Ti ilẹ̀kùn lẹ́yìn rẹ.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'lọ' (go) and 'wá' (come) with another verb to form compound commands.
examples: Lọ mú omi wá – Go bring water.
Wá jẹun – Come eat.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'ní' means 'at', 'sórí' means 'on top of', 'nínú' means 'inside'.
examples: Ó wà lórí tábìlì – It's on the table.
Ó wà nínú àpótí – It's inside the box.

dialogue.speaker: Ìyá (Mother)
dialogue.text: Ọmọ mi, lọ mú kẹ́túlù wá nínú ìdáná.
dialogue.translation: My child, go bring the kettle from the kitchen.

dialogue.speaker: Ọmọ (Child)
dialogue.text: Kí ni màá fi ṣe?
dialogue.translation: What will I do with it?

dialogue.speaker: Ìyá
dialogue.text: A máa bu omi mu. Wá gbé e wá sí pálọ́ọ̀.
dialogue.translation: We will fetch water to drink. Bring it to the parlour.

dialogue.speaker: Ọmọ
dialogue.text: Níbo ni omi wà?
dialogue.translation: Where is the water?

dialogue.speaker: Ìyá
dialogue.text: Omi wà nínú fírììjì.
dialogue.translation: The water is in the fridge.

dialogue.speaker: Ọmọ
dialogue.text: Ó dára, màá lọ.
dialogue.translation: Okay, I'll go.

culturalNotes.title: The Compound
culturalNotes.content: Traditional Yoruba homes are compounds with multiple rooms around a courtyard. Extended family members often live together, and the compound head (Baálé) oversees the household.

culturalNotes.title: Verandah Life
culturalNotes.content: In the evenings, the verandah (pàràńgà) becomes a social hub where neighbours chat, children play, and elders rest. It's a vital community space.

practiceExercises.question: What is the Yoruba word for 'kitchen'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ìdáná' is the kitchen.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Go bring the kettle'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Lọ mú kẹ́túlù wá' is the correct command.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'sórí' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'sórí' means 'on top of'.

practiceExercises.question: Which room is used to receive guests?
practiceExercises.explanation: The parlour (pálọ́ọ̀) is for receiving guests.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Ó wà nínú àpótí', where is the item?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Nínú àpótí' means inside the box.

tips: Use these words when giving chores – 'lọ mú omi wá' – to reinforce learning.
If you're staying with family in Nigeria, knowing these terms helps you navigate the house.
Understanding household terms can be useful if you're visiting a colleague's home.
When living with your spouse, use these words to describe your shared space.
If you're renting a place, these words will help you discuss repairs or furniture.
Practice giving commands to family members.
Pay attention to prepositions – they change meaning.

levels.title: Level 12: Family
levels.description: Specific terms for 'My mother’s sibling' vs. 'Father’s sibling.' Grandparents, Siblings. Cultural focus: Why you cannot date someone you call 'Sister.'
learningObjectives: Identify and name various family members
Distinguish between paternal and maternal relatives
Understand the cultural taboo of dating a 'sibling'

vocabulary.example: Bàbá mi jẹ́ olùkọ́.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Also used as a respectful title for any older man.

vocabulary.example: Ìyá mi ń ṣe oníṣòwò.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Also a title of respect for older women.

vocabulary.example: Ìyá àgbà mi ń gbé ní ìlú.
Bàbá àgbà mi jẹ́ ọ̀jẹ̀.
Ìyá òkàn mi wá láti Ìbàdàn.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Often used for mother's brother or sister.

vocabulary.example: Bàbá òkàn mi ni bàbá mi bàtà.
Àbúrò mi ń kọ́ èdè Yorùbá.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Used for both younger brother and sister.

vocabulary.example: Ẹ̀gbọ́n mi ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní ìlú òkèrè.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Respect term; you must address elders as 'ẹ̀gbọ́n' even if not biological.

vocabulary.example: Mo ní ọmọ mẹ́ta.
Gbogbo mọ̀lẹ́bí wa wà níbi ìgbéyẹ́wó.

grammarPoints.explanation: To say 'my', use 'mi' after the noun. 'Your' is 'rẹ' (singular informal), 'yín' (plural/polite). 'His/her' is 'rẹ̀'.
examples: Bàbá mi – my father.
Ìyá rẹ – your mother.
Ẹ̀gbọ́n rẹ̀ – his/her elder sibling.

grammarPoints.explanation: To specify 'mother's side', you can say 'láti ọ̀dọ̀ ìyá mi' (from my mother's side). 'Father's side' – 'láti ọ̀dọ̀ bàbá mi'.
examples: Arábìnrin bàbá mi – my father's sister (aunt).
Arákùnrin ìyá mi – my mother's brother (uncle).

dialogue.speaker: Kéhìndé
dialogue.text: Ta ni obìnrin yẹn?
dialogue.translation: Who is that woman?

dialogue.speaker: Táyé
dialogue.text: Ìyá òkàn mi ni, láti ọ̀dọ̀ bàbá mi.
dialogue.translation: She's my aunt from my father's side.

dialogue.speaker: Kéhìndé
dialogue.text: Ṣé ẹ̀gbọ́n bàbá rẹ ni?
dialogue.translation: Is she your father's elder sister?

dialogue.speaker: Táyé
dialogue.text: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, ìyá àgbà ni fún mi.
dialogue.translation: Yes, she is like a grandmother to me.

dialogue.speaker: Kéhìndé
dialogue.text: Ó yẹ kí n kí i.
dialogue.translation: I should greet her.

dialogue.speaker: Táyé
dialogue.text: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, ẹ jọ̀wọ́.
dialogue.translation: Yes, please do.

culturalNotes.title: The 'Sister' Taboo
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba culture, you cannot romantically pursue anyone you address as 'ẹ̀gbọ́n' or 'àbúrò', even if not blood-related. These terms create a familial bond that makes dating taboo.

culturalNotes.title: Extended Family Terms
culturalNotes.content: Yoruba has specific terms for each type of aunt/uncle based on whether they are older/younger than the parent and on which side. For example, 'Ìyá àgbà' is mother's older sister, also called 'Ìyá ńlá'.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'ẹ̀gbọ́n' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ̀gbọ́n' is an older sibling or cousin.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'my mother's brother'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Arákùnrin ìyá mi' means 'brother of my mother'.

practiceExercises.question: Which term is used for 'grandmother'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ìyá àgbà' means grandmother.

practiceExercises.question: Why can't you date someone you call 'ẹ̀gbọ́n'?
options: It creates a sibling-like bond that makes it taboo
practiceExercises.explanation: Calling someone 'ẹ̀gbọ́n' establishes a familial relationship, making romance inappropriate.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'younger sibling'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Àbúrò' is the younger sibling.

tips: Teach children the difference between ẹ̀gbọ́n and àbúrò – it's essential for family harmony.
When visiting Nigeria, use these terms correctly – it shows respect and avoids awkwardness.
If a colleague calls you 'ẹ̀gbọ́n', it's a sign of respect, not a literal claim of kinship.
Learn your spouse's family terms – it helps you navigate relationships with in-laws.
If you're dating a Yoruba person, be careful: calling their sibling by the wrong term can cause offense.
Remember: 'ẹ̀gbọ́n' is respect, 'àbúrò' is affectionate.
When in doubt, ask how someone is related before using a term.

levels.title: Level 13: Body
levels.description: Parts of the body – practical usage: 'My head is spinning' (illness), 'Open your mouth' (at the clinic).

vocabulary.example: Orí mi ń yí.
vocabulary.culturalNote: 'Orí' also refers to one's destiny or spiritual head.

vocabulary.example: Ojú mi ń dun mi.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Eyes are considered windows to the soul.

vocabulary.example: Imú rẹ̀ ń gbọ́n.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Used in phrases like 'imú kò gbọ́n' (nose doesn't shake) meaning no problem.

vocabulary.example: Ṣí ẹnu rẹ sílẹ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Important for eating and speaking; 'ẹnu' also means 'opening'.

vocabulary.example: Ó fọ apá rẹ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Also means 'side' as in 'apá òtún' (right side).

vocabulary.example: Fọ ọwọ́ rẹ kó o tó jẹun.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Hands are used for eating; washing before meals is essential.

vocabulary.example: Ẹsẹ̀ mi ń dun mi.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Barefoot is common, but shoes are worn outside.

vocabulary.example: Ìkùn mi ń pa mí.
vocabulary.culturalNote: 'Ìkùn' is also used for pregnancy: 'ó lóyún' (she is pregnant) literally 'she has a stomach'.

vocabulary.example: Ọkàn mi ń fọ́.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Metaphorically used for emotions; 'ọkàn tútù' means calmness.

vocabulary.example: Ó ṣẹ egungun ẹsẹ̀ rẹ̀.

grammarPoints.explanation: To say something hurts, use 'ń dun mi' after the body part.
examples: Orí mi ń dun mi – My head hurts.
Ẹsẹ̀ mi ń dun mi – My leg hurts.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use the verb base for commands, often with 'jọ̀wọ́' for politeness.
examples: Ṣí ẹnu rẹ – Open your mouth.
Mi í mí jinlẹ̀ – Breathe deeply.

dialogue.speaker: Oníṣègùn (Doctor)
dialogue.text: Kí ló ń ṣe ọ́?
dialogue.translation: What's wrong with you?

dialogue.speaker: Aláìsàn (Patient)
dialogue.text: Orí mi ń dun mi, ìkùn mi sì ń pa mí.
dialogue.translation: My head hurts and my stomach aches.

dialogue.speaker: Oníṣègùn
dialogue.text: Ṣí ẹnu rẹ, jẹ́ kí n wo ọ́.
dialogue.translation: Open your mouth, let me examine you.

dialogue.speaker: Aláìsàn
dialogue.text: Òò, mo ṣe.
dialogue.translation: Okay, I'm doing it.

dialogue.speaker: Oníṣègùn
dialogue.text: Ó ṣeé ṣe kó jẹ́ ibà. Màá fún ọ lóògùn.
dialogue.translation: It might be malaria. I'll give you medicine.

culturalNotes.title: Traditional Medicine
culturalNotes.content: Many Yoruba people consult traditional healers (oníṣègùn) who use herbs and spiritual practices. It's common to try traditional remedies before visiting a hospital.

culturalNotes.title: Illness and Spirituality
culturalNotes.content: Some ailments are attributed to spiritual causes. You might hear 'ọtá lù mí' (an enemy attacked me). Prayers and rituals may accompany medical treatment.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'My head hurts'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Orí mi ń dun mi' is correct.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ṣí ẹnu rẹ' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ṣí ẹnu rẹ' means open your mouth.

practiceExercises.question: Which body part is 'ọwọ́'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọwọ́' means hand.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Ìkùn mi ń pa mí', what is wrong?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ìkùn' is stomach, so stomach ache.

practiceExercises.question: What is the Yoruba word for 'heart'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọkàn' is heart.

tips: When your child is sick, ask 'Kí ló ń ṣe ọ́?' and have them point and say the word.
If you feel unwell in Nigeria, use these phrases to describe symptoms to a doctor or chemist.
In a corporate clinic, being able to describe symptoms in Yoruba can help if the staff is more comfortable in it.
When your spouse is ill, use these caring phrases to ask what hurts.
If you visit a traditional healer, these words are essential.
Learn the words for common ailments like ibà (malaria), efọ́n (cough).
When in pain, say 'ń dun mi' clearly.

levels.title: Level 14: Colours
levels.description: Describing clothing: 'I am wearing blue,' Ankara, George wrapper. Cultural focus: Colour symbolism in weddings/funerals.

vocabulary.example: Aṣọ funfun ni wọ́n wọ̀ sí ìgbéyẹ́wó.
vocabulary.culturalNote: White symbolises purity and is common at weddings and naming ceremonies.

vocabulary.example: Aṣọ dúdú ni a wọ̀ fún òkú.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Black is mourning colour, worn at funerals.

vocabulary.example: Aṣọ pupa wúwo lójú ọmọ Yorùbá.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Red can symbolise danger or boldness; also used in chieftaincy ceremonies.

vocabulary.example: Mo wọ̀ búlúù lónìí.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Borrowed from English; common in everyday wear.

vocabulary.example: Aláwọ̀ ewé ni àmì ìrètí.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Green symbolises life, fertility, and hope.

vocabulary.example: Ó wọ̀ ọ̀sàn mọ́tò.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Also the word for orange fruit.

vocabulary.example: Aṣọ yèlò wà ní gbogbo ọjà.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Borrowed; also associated with turmeric (ata pupa).

vocabulary.example: Aṣọ Ankára ló wà ní ọjà.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Vibrant, colourful fabric used for special occasions.

vocabulary.example: Jọ́jì jẹ́ aṣọ olówó.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Expensive lace worn at weddings and parties.

vocabulary.example: Àdìrẹ jẹ́ aṣọ ìbílẹ̀.

grammarPoints.explanation: To say something is a colour, you can use 'aláwọ̀' + colour name, or simply state the colour after the noun.
examples: Aṣọ aláwọ̀ pupa – Red cloth.
Ó wọ̀ búlúù – He/She wears blue.
grammarPoints.pattern: Noun + aláwọ̀ + colour / Subject + wọ̀ + colour

grammarPoints.explanation: To say 'I am wearing' use 'Mo ń wọ̀'.
examples: Mo ń wọ̀ búlúù lónìí – I am wearing blue today.
Ó ń wọ̀ Ankára – She is wearing Ankara.

dialogue.speaker: Adùnní
dialogue.text: Aṣọ rẹ dára gan. Kí ni àwọ̀ rẹ̀?
dialogue.translation: Your outfit is beautiful. What colour is it?

dialogue.speaker: Fúnmiláyọ̀
dialogue.text: Aláwọ̀ búlúù àti funfun ni. Mo rà á ní ọjà.
dialogue.translation: It's blue and white. I bought it at the market.

dialogue.speaker: Adùnní
dialogue.text: Ṣé Ankára ni?
dialogue.translation: Is it Ankara?

dialogue.speaker: Fúnmiláyọ̀
dialogue.text: Rárá, Jọ́jì ni. Aso ìgbéyẹ́wó ni.
dialogue.translation: No, it's George. It's for a wedding.

dialogue.speaker: Adùnní
dialogue.text: Ó yẹ ọ́ gan. Àwọ̀ funfun sì dára fún ìgbéyẹ́wó.
dialogue.translation: It suits you very well. White is good for weddings.

culturalNotes.title: Colour Symbolism
culturalNotes.content: At Yoruba weddings, the couple and their families often wear matching asọ ẹbí (family cloth) in colours chosen for the occasion. White is common, but other colours may represent family unity. At funerals, black or dark blue (búlúù dúdú) is worn; red is generally avoided.

culturalNotes.title: Adire and Ankara
culturalNotes.content: Adire is a traditional resist-dyed cloth from Abeokuta, often indigo. Ankara is mass-produced wax print, popular across Africa. Each has cultural significance and is worn with pride.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I am wearing blue'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo ń wọ̀ búlúù' is correct.

practiceExercises.question: What colour is associated with mourning in Yoruba culture?
practiceExercises.explanation: Black (dúdú) is mourning colour.

practiceExercises.question: What is 'Ankara'?
practiceExercises.explanation: Ankara is a printed African fabric.

practiceExercises.question: Which word means 'white'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Funfun' is white.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Ó wọ̀ pupa', what are they wearing?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Pupa' means red.

tips: When dressing children, talk about colours in Yoruba – 'a wọ̀ pupa lónìí'.
Describe your outfit in Yoruba on social media – it's trendy.
If attending a traditional event, knowing colour symbolism helps you dress appropriately.
Discuss with your spouse which asọ ẹbí colours to choose for family events.
When buying fabric, use colour names to describe what you want.
Practice by describing the colours of objects around you.
Remember that some colour names are borrowed from English.

levels.title: Level 15: Morning Routine
levels.description: Morning routine – simple past tense: 'I bathed,' 'I ate,' 'I left the house.'
learningObjectives: Describe morning activities using simple past tense
Use time expressions like 'láràárọ̀' (in the morning)

vocabulary.example: Mo jí ní àgọ́ mẹ́fà òwúrọ̀.
Mo wẹ̀ lẹ́yìn tí mo jí.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Bathing is done twice daily in many households.

vocabulary.example: Mo jẹun kí n tó lọ sí iṣẹ́.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Breakfast is often light: tea, bread, or leftovers.

vocabulary.example: Mo mu omi gbígbóná.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Drinking warm water or tea is common.

vocabulary.example: Mo wọ̀ aṣọ iṣẹ́.
Mo lọ sí ilé iṣẹ́ ní àgọ́ méje.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Many leave home early to avoid traffic.

vocabulary.example: Mo padà wálé ní ìrọ̀lẹ́.
Mo kọ́ èdè Yorùbá láràárọ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Many study or read in the morning.

vocabulary.example: Mo gbàdúrà kí n tó jáde.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Prayer is an essential part of morning routine for many.

vocabulary.example: Mo yára nítorí mo ti pẹ́.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Hurrying is common in urban areas.

grammarPoints.explanation: Yoruba verbs do not conjugate for tense. Past is indicated by context or time adverbs like 'lánàá' (yesterday) or 'láràárọ̀' (in the morning).
examples: Mo jẹun láràárọ̀ – I ate in the morning.
Ó wẹ̀ lánàá – He bathed yesterday.

grammarPoints.concept: Sequencing with 'kí n tó' (before I) and 'lẹ́yìn' (after)
grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'kí n tó' to say 'before I...' and 'lẹ́yìn' to say 'after...'.
examples: Mo wẹ̀ kí n tó jẹun – I bathed before I ate.
Lẹ́yìn tí mo jẹun, mo lọ – After I ate, I went.

dialogue.speaker: Tọ́lá
dialogue.text: Kí ló o ṣe láràárọ̀?
dialogue.translation: What did you do this morning?

dialogue.speaker: Jibọ́lá
dialogue.text: Mo jí ní àgọ́ márùn-ún, mo wẹ̀, mo sì jẹun.
dialogue.translation: I woke up at five, bathed, and ate.

dialogue.speaker: Tọ́lá
dialogue.text: Ṣé o gbàdúrà kí o tó jáde?
dialogue.translation: Did you pray before going out?

dialogue.speaker: Jibọ́lá
dialogue.text: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, mo gbàdúrà kí n tó wọ̀ aṣọ.
dialogue.translation: Yes, I prayed before dressing.

dialogue.speaker: Tọ́lá
dialogue.text: Nígbà wo lo lọ sí iṣẹ́?
dialogue.translation: When did you go to work?

dialogue.speaker: Jibọ́lá
dialogue.text: Mo lọ ní àgọ́ keje.
dialogue.translation: I went at seven.

culturalNotes.title: Morning Prayers
culturalNotes.content: Many Yoruba families start the day with morning prayers (àdúrà òwúrọ̀). The head of the family leads, and everyone participates. It's a time to seek blessings for the day.

culturalNotes.title: Early Rising
culturalNotes.content: The Yoruba saying 'Àrò ọjọ́ ni òwúrọ̀' (the morning is the foundation of the day) emphasises the importance of starting the day early and productively.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I bathed'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo wẹ̀' is the past (context makes it past).

practiceExercises.question: What does 'kí n tó' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'kí n tó' means 'before I'.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I ate before I left'?
options: Mo jẹun kí n tó lọ
Mo jẹun lẹ́yìn tí mo lọ
Mo lọ kí n tó jẹun
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo jẹun kí n tó lọ' is correct.

practiceExercises.question: Which word means 'to pray'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Gbàdúrà' means to pray.

practiceExercises.question: If you want to say 'I woke up at six', you say:
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Àgọ́ mẹ́fà' is six o'clock.

tips: Encourage children to describe their morning routine in Yoruba – it builds vocabulary.
Share your morning routine on social media in Yoruba – it's relatable.
When colleagues ask how your morning was, use these phrases to respond.
Talk about your morning with your spouse – it's a daily bonding activity.
If you live in Nigeria, your morning routine will likely include these activities.
Use time words like 'láràárọ̀' (in the morning), 'lọ́sàn-án' (in the afternoon), 'lálẹ́' (in the evening).
Practice sequencing with 'kí n tó' and 'lẹ́yìn'.

levels.title: Level 16: Scenarios
levels.description: Unique Nigerian situations: 'The light has gone' (power outage), 'Stop here!' (Okada), 'Hold your change.'
learningObjectives: Understand and respond to common Nigerian scenarios
Use phrases related to power outage, transportation, and transactions

vocabulary.translation: The light is gone / Power outage
vocabulary.example: Ìmọ́lẹ̀ kú, a ó máa lo fìtílà.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Frequent in Nigeria; people use generators or lanterns.

vocabulary.example: Mú fìtílà wá, òkùnkùn bò mí.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Common during outages; also refers to kerosene lamp.

vocabulary.example: Dúró níbí, mo fẹ́ sọ̀kalẹ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Used in taxis or okadas to indicate drop-off point.

vocabulary.example: Mo gun okáda lọ sí ọjà.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Okada is a common, fast mode of transport, but sometimes banned in city centres.

vocabulary.example: Ó gun kẹ́kẹ́ lọ sí ibi iṣẹ́.
vocabulary.culturalNote: General term; okada is specifically commercial.

vocabulary.translation: Hold your change / Keep the change
vocabulary.example: Dá owó dúró, ó ṣeun.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Often said when you don't want the change or as a tip.

vocabulary.example: Tìrù mú mi lára lónìí.
Gẹ̀sì ti tóbi lórí.
Wọn ń ta gẹ̀sì ní púpù.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Borrowed from English; filling station is 'ilé epo'.

vocabulary.example: Ọ̀nà dí lónìí nítorí òjò.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Roads can be blocked by rain, accidents, or protests.

grammarPoints.explanation: The verb 'kú' (die) is used metaphorically for things that stop working, like light, battery, etc.
examples: Ìmọ́lẹ̀ kú – The light died (power outage).
Bátìrí kú – The battery is dead.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use direct commands like 'dúró' (stop) to the driver.
examples: Dúró níbí – Stop here.
Fa sí apá òtún – Pull over to the right.

dialogue.speaker: Erù (Passenger)
dialogue.text: Ọkọ̀, dúró níbí!
dialogue.translation: Driver, stop here!

dialogue.speaker: Awakọ̀ (Driver)
dialogue.text: Níbo? Níbí yìí?
dialogue.translation: Where? Right here?

dialogue.speaker: Erù
dialogue.text: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, dúró. Èló ni?
dialogue.translation: Yes, stop. How much?

dialogue.speaker: Awakọ̀
dialogue.text: Ọ́ọ́ń ṣe márùn-ún naira.
dialogue.translation: It's five hundred naira.

dialogue.speaker: Erù
dialogue.text: Ẹ gba ẹgbẹ̀rún, dá owó dúró.
dialogue.translation: Take one thousand, keep the change.

dialogue.speaker: Awakọ̀
dialogue.text: Ẹ ṣé púpọ̀. Kí ọlọ́run bù kún un yín.
dialogue.translation: Thank you very much. May God bless you.

culturalNotes.title: Okada and Keke
culturalNotes.content: Okada (motorcycles) and Keke NAPEP (tricycles) are ubiquitous in Nigerian cities. They weave through traffic and are often faster than cars. Always negotiate fare before boarding.

culturalNotes.title: Power Outage (Lights Out)
culturalNotes.content: PHCN (Power Holding Company of Nigeria) is notorious for erratic supply. Most homes have generators (mọ́tò) and inverters. When the light goes, you'll hear 'Ìmọ́lẹ̀ kú' or 'Light don go'.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'The light has gone out'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ìmọ́lẹ̀ kú' is the correct phrase.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'dúró níbí' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'dúró níbí' means 'stop here'.

practiceExercises.question: What is 'okáda'?
practiceExercises.explanation: Okada is a motorcycle taxi.

practiceExercises.question: If you want to keep the change, you say:
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Dá owó dúró' means hold/keep the change.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'tìrù' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Tìrù' is traffic jam (from 'go-slow').

tips: When there's a power outage, use the phrase with your children – 'Ìmọ́lẹ̀ kú, ẹ mú fìtílà.'
If you're taking an okada, practice saying 'dúró níbí' firmly.
When stuck in traffic, you can say 'tìrù mú mi lára' to colleagues to explain lateness.
Discuss with your spouse how to handle common scenarios like power outages.
If you're new, these phrases will help you survive daily life.
When using okada, always agree on the fare before starting the journey.
Keep small change handy for taxis and okadas.

levels.title: Level 17: Work
levels.description: Professions, especially informal economy: 'I sell clothes,' 'I run a canteen,' 'I am a student.'
learningObjectives: Describe what you do for a living

vocabulary.example: Mo jẹ́ oníṣòwò, mo ń ta aṣọ.
Ó jẹ́ olùkọ́ ní ilé ìwé alákọ̀ọ́bẹ̀rẹ̀.
Adájọ́ sọ pé ó jàre.
Bàbá mi jẹ́ ọ̀jẹ̀ ọkọ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Commercial drivers are a vital part of the economy.

vocabulary.example: Alágbẹ̀dẹ tún ọkọ̀ mi ṣe.
Oníṣẹ́ abẹ ran aṣọ fún mi.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Tailors are abundant; they make custom clothing.

vocabulary.example: Ó ń ṣiṣẹ́ onílé oúnjẹ ní ọjà.
Àgbẹ̀ ń gbin iṣu.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Farming is the backbone of rural economy.

vocabulary.example: Mo ṣì jẹ́ ọmọ ilé ìwé.
Ó wà láìṣiṣẹ́ ní báyìí.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Unemployment is a major issue, often discussed.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'jẹ́' to say 'is/are' for professions. Often omitted in casual speech.
examples: Mo jẹ́ oníṣòwò – I am a trader.
Ó jẹ́ olùkọ́ – He is a teacher.

grammarPoints.explanation: To say someone works as, use 'ń ṣiṣẹ́' + profession or description.
examples: Ó ń ṣiṣẹ́ oníṣòwò – He works as a trader.
Wọ́n ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní ilé iṣẹ́ – They work at an office.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Kí ni iṣẹ́ rẹ?
dialogue.translation: What is your job?

dialogue.speaker: Táyé
dialogue.text: Mo jẹ́ oníṣòwò, mo ń ta bàtà ní ọjà.
dialogue.translation: I am a trader, I sell shoes at the market.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Ṣé o ní ilé ìtajà?
dialogue.translation: Do you have a shop?

dialogue.speaker: Táyé
dialogue.text: Rárá, mo ń tà lójú pópó.
dialogue.translation: No, I sell on the roadside.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Ó ṣe é. Ọlọ́run á ràn ọ́ lọ́wọ́.
dialogue.translation: That's okay. God will help you.

culturalNotes.title: Informal Economy
culturalNotes.content: A huge percentage of Nigerians work in the informal sector: street vendors, market traders, artisans. It's a vibrant, essential part of the economy.

culturalNotes.title: Respect for All Work
culturalNotes.content: Yoruba culture respects hard work regardless of the profession. It's common to greet traders with 'Ẹ kú iṣẹ́' (well done on your work).

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I am a trader'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Oníṣòwò' means trader/businessperson.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'onílé oúnjẹ' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Onílé oúnjẹ' is someone who owns a food place.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'He works as a farmer'?
practiceExercises.explanation: All are acceptable ways to express occupation.

practiceExercises.question: What is a 'ọ̀jẹ̀'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọ̀jẹ̀' is a commercial driver.

practiceExercises.question: If someone is unemployed, you say:
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Láìṣiṣẹ́' means without work.

tips: Teach children about different professions and what family members do.
When people ask what you do, use these phrases – even if you're still studying.
In networking, clearly state your profession using 'Mo jẹ́ ...'.
Know your spouse's profession and be able to talk about it.
If you're working in Nigeria, these words help you understand the job market.
When talking about informal work, be specific: 'Mo ń ta ẹ̀ja' (I sell fish).
Use 'ẹ kú iṣẹ́' to greet anyone working.

levels.title: Level 18: Time
levels.description: Nigerian time concepts: 'Now now' (immediate), 'Small time' (soon), 'Morning' (anytime before noon). Confirming appointments.

vocabulary.translation: What time is it? (Literally: o'clock how many?)
vocabulary.example: Àgọ́ mélòó? – Àgọ́ mẹ́fà.
A ó pàdé ní àgọ́ mẹ́fà òwúrọ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Numbers 1-10 are used; for minutes, add 'ìṣẹ́jú'.

vocabulary.example: Wá nísisìnyí!
Mo ń bọ̀ báyìí báyìí.

vocabulary.translation: For a short time / Small time
vocabulary.example: Dúró fúngbà díẹ̀, màá padà.
A ó pàdé lọ́la.
Mo rí i lánàá.
Kí ló ń ṣẹlẹ̀ lówọ́ọ́?
Àgọ́ méje ìdajì – Half past seven.
Ìṣẹ́jú márùn-ún kù sí àgọ́ mẹ́jọ – Five minutes to eight.

grammarPoints.explanation: Time is given as 'àgọ́' + number. For minutes past, use 'ìṣẹ́jú' (minutes) + 'rékọjá' (past). For minutes to, use 'kù sí'.
examples: Àgọ́ mẹ́fà – 6:00.
Ìṣẹ́jú mẹ́wàá rékọjá àgọ́ méje – 7:10.
Ìṣẹ́jú márùn-ún kù sí àgọ́ méjọ – 7:55.
grammarPoints.pattern: àgọ́ + number / ìṣẹ́jú + number + (rékọjá/kù sí) + àgọ́ + number

grammarPoints.explanation: Nigerian time is often flexible. 'Now now' means immediately, 'small time' means soon, but could be minutes to hours.
examples: Mo ń bọ̀ báyìí báyìí – I'm coming right away.
Dúró fúngbà díẹ̀ – Wait a little while.
grammarPoints.pattern: Use adverbs: báyìí báyìí, fúngbà díẹ̀

dialogue.speaker: Túnjí
dialogue.text: Àgọ́ mélòó ló ń ṣe nísisìnyí?
dialogue.translation: What time is it now?

dialogue.speaker: Fẹ́mi
dialogue.text: Àgọ́ mẹ́fà àbọ̀ (6:30). Kí ló dé?
dialogue.translation: Half past six. What's up?

dialogue.speaker: Túnjí
dialogue.text: Mo ní ìpàdé ní àgọ́ méje. Ṣé màá lọ nísisìnyí?
dialogue.translation: I have a meeting at seven. Should I go now?

dialogue.speaker: Fẹ́mi
dialogue.text: Ó ṣì ní ìṣẹ́jú ọgbọ̀n. Lọ báyìí báyìí.
dialogue.translation: You still have thirty minutes. Go right away.

dialogue.speaker: Túnjí
dialogue.text: Ó dára. A ó pàdé lọ́la.
dialogue.translation: Okay. We'll meet tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: Fẹ́mi
dialogue.text: Hmm, ṣeé ṣe. Báyìí báyìí ni mo máa wà.
dialogue.translation: Okay, possible. I'll be here around that time (flexible).

culturalNotes.title: Nigerian Time
culturalNotes.content: Nigerian time is famously flexible. Events may start hours late. However, for formal appointments, it's best to be punctual, but expect others to be on 'African time'.

culturalNotes.title: 'Now Now' vs 'Now'
culturalNotes.content: 'Now now' means immediately. 'Now' could mean anytime soon. Understanding this nuance is crucial.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'What time is it?'
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Àgọ́ mélòó?' is correct.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'báyìí báyìí' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Báyìí báyìí' means right away.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'half past seven'?
practiceExercises.explanation: Both 'ìdajì' and 'àbọ̀' are used for half.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Dúró fúngbà díẹ̀', they mean:
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Fúngbà díẹ̀' means a short time.

practiceExercises.question: What is 'lọ́la'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Lọ́la' means tomorrow.

tips: Teach children to use 'báyìí báyìí' for urgency.
When friends say 'I'm coming now', it might be an hour – ask 'báyìí báyìí?' to confirm.
In business, confirm times clearly: 'A ó pàdé ní àgọ́ méje dójú' (7:00 sharp).
When planning events with family, agree on what 'small time' means to avoid frustration.
Learn to be flexible with time, but also use precise phrases when needed.
For exact appointments, add 'dójú' (sharp) – 'àgọ́ méje dójú'.
Be patient with 'Nigerian time' – it's a cultural norm.

levels.title: Level 19: Weather
levels.description: Harmattan, Rainy season, Dry season. 'The sun is hot today,' 'I am cold.' Weather as social lubricant.

vocabulary.example: Ọ̀rọ̀ọ̀rún gbóná lónìí.
Ó gbóná gan-an lónìí.
Ó tutù nísisìnyí, mo fẹ́ wọ̀ búńbá.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Cold during harmattan or rainy season.

vocabulary.example: Òjò ń rọ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Rain can be sudden and heavy.

vocabulary.example: Atẹ́gùn ń fẹ́ lónìí.
Ìgbà ẹ̀rùn bẹ̀rẹ̀ ní October.
Ìgbà òjò máa ń bẹ̀rẹ̀ ní April.
Harmattan ti dé, atẹ́gùn tutù.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Season of dry, cold wind, usually December–February.

vocabulary.example: Efúùfú bo gbogbo nǹkan ní Harmattan.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Harmattan brings dust haze, reducing visibility.

vocabulary.example: Ṣé o gbọ́ ààmì ojú ọjọ́ lónìí?

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'Ó' as an impersonal subject to describe weather.
examples: Ó gbóná – It is hot.
Ó tutù – It is cold.
Ó ń rọ̀ – It is raining.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Ìgbà' means season or time. Use it to talk about seasons.
examples: Ìgbà òjò – Rainy season.
Ìgbà ẹ̀rùn – Dry season.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Ọ̀rọ̀ọ̀rún gbóná lónìí, àbí?
dialogue.translation: The sun is hot today, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, ó gbóná ju. Òjò ò rọ̀ láìpẹ́.
dialogue.translation: Yes, it's too hot. It hasn't rained recently.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Ṣùgbọ́n Harmattan ń bọ̀, a ó tutù.
dialogue.translation: But Harmattan is coming, we'll be cold.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Mo fẹ́ràn atẹ́gùn Harmattan, ṣùgbọ́n efúùfú ń kọ́ àìsàn.
dialogue.translation: I love Harmattan breeze, but dust brings sickness.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Ó dára, ká máa bó ara wa lójú efúùfú.
dialogue.translation: Okay, let's protect ourselves from dust.

culturalNotes.title: Weather as Small Talk
culturalNotes.content: Just like anywhere, weather is a common icebreaker. 'Ó gbóná lónìí' (it's hot today) is a standard opening line.

culturalNotes.title: Harmattan
culturalNotes.content: Harmattan is a unique West African season. The cold, dusty wind dries the skin and brings respiratory issues. People wear heavier clothing and use moisturizers.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'It's hot today'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ó gbóná lónìí' means it's hot today.

practiceExercises.question: What is 'Harmattan'?
practiceExercises.explanation: Harmattan is a dry, dusty season.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'It is raining'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ó ń rọ̀' means it's raining.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ìgbà òjò' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ìgbà òjò' is rainy season.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Ó tutù', they mean:
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ó tutù' means it's cold.

tips: Talk about the weather with kids – 'Ṣé ó tutù lónìí?' – it's easy conversation.
Use weather as a chat starter: 'Ó gbóná gan, ṣe o rí?' (It's so hot, you see?)
In meetings, a comment about the weather can ease tension.
Discuss how the weather affects your day with your spouse.
Prepare for Harmattan by having lip balm and skin cream.
In Harmattan, you'll hear 'efúùfú' often – cover your nose and mouth.
Use 'Ó ń rọ̀' for rain, but if it's pouring, say 'Òjò ń rọ̀ lágídí' (it's raining heavily).

levels.title: Test 2
levels.description: Assessment: Tell a story about your day – waking up, leaving, a problem you solved, and returning home.
learningObjectives: Demonstrate comprehension of home, family, body, colours, morning routine, scenarios, work, time, and weather
Narrate a simple story in Yoruba

practiceExercises.question: You wake up in the morning. What do you say?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo jí' means I woke up; with time, it's the start of a story.

practiceExercises.question: Before leaving home, you pray. How do you say that?
options: Mo gbàdúrà kí n tó jáde
Mo jáde kí n tó gbàdúrà
Mo gbàdúrà lẹ́yìn tí mo jáde
practiceExercises.explanation: Praying before going out is 'Mo gbàdúrà kí n tó jáde'.

practiceExercises.question: On your way, you get stuck in traffic. What word do you use?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Tìrù' means traffic jam.

practiceExercises.question: You arrive at work. You are a teacher. How do you say 'I am a teacher'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Olùkọ́' is teacher.

practiceExercises.question: At work, you need to ask a colleague the time. What do you say?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Àgọ́ mélòó?' asks the time.

practiceExercises.question: After work, you return home. How do you say 'I returned home'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo padà wálé' means I returned home.

practiceExercises.question: At home, the power goes out. What do you say?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ìmọ́lẹ̀ kú' is used for power outage.

practiceExercises.question: You use a lantern. What is 'lantern' in Yoruba?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Fìtílà' is lantern.

practiceExercises.question: The next morning, it's very cold because of Harmattan. How do you say 'It's cold'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ó tutù' means it's cold.

practiceExercises.question: Which of these sentences correctly sequences your day?
options: Mo jí, mo wẹ̀, mo jẹun, mo lọ sí iṣẹ́.
Mo lọ sí iṣẹ́, mo jí, mo wẹ̀.
Mo jẹun, mo jí, mo wẹ̀, mo lọ.
Mo padà wálé, mo jí, mo wẹ̀.
practiceExercises.explanation: The logical order: wake, bathe, eat, go to work.

tips: Ask your child to tell you their day in Yoruba – it's great practice.
Try narrating your day to a friend in Yoruba – even if imperfect.
Practice telling a colleague about your day – it builds fluency.
Share your day with your spouse in Yoruba – it's intimate.
If you live in Nigeria, narrating your day helps you process the chaos!
Review vocabulary from levels 11-19 before starting.
Take your time with each question.
You can retry if needed.

levels.title: Level 21: Health
levels.description: Asking after someone’s health: 'How is your body?' 'I am tired,' 'I am coughing.' Empathy: 'Sorry for the pain.'
learningObjectives: Ask about someone's health and well‑being
Express sympathy for pain or illness

vocabulary.translation: How is your body? / How are you feeling?
vocabulary.example: Báwo ni ara rẹ? – Ara mi ò yá.
vocabulary.culturalNote: A common way to ask about someone's health, especially if they've been unwell.

vocabulary.example: Lẹ́yìn iṣẹ́ lónìí, ó rẹ̀ mí.
Mo ń wú kọ́ọ́ nítorí efúùfú.

vocabulary.translation: It hurts me / I am in pain
vocabulary.example: Orí mi ń dùn mí.
Mo ní ibà, mo ń wárìwì.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Malaria is very common; 'ibà' is fever/malaria.

vocabulary.example: Ẹ kú ìrora, ẹ máa yára gbàdúrà.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Said to someone suffering from pain or illness.

vocabulary.example: Mo dúpẹ́, ó dára báyìí.
vocabulary.culturalNote: A common response when asked about health.

vocabulary.example: Ara kò yá, ì bá sinmi.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Often used to explain absence or low energy.

vocabulary.translation: He/She has a fever (lit. it is hot)
vocabulary.example: Ọmọ náà ń gbóná, ó ní ibà.
Mú oògùn yìí, ì á sàn.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Mo ní' means 'I have' (illness, thing). 'Mo ń' + verb indicates ongoing action.
examples: Mo ní ibà – I have malaria.
Mo ń wú kọ́ọ́ – I am coughing.
grammarPoints.pattern: Subject + ní + noun / Subject + ń + verb

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'ẹ kú' + condition to express sympathy or acknowledge a state.
examples: Ẹ kú ìrora – Sorry for your pain.
Ẹ kú iṣẹ́ – Well done (acknowledging work).

dialogue.speaker: Kúnlé
dialogue.text: Báwo ni ara rẹ? Mo gbọ́ pé o ń ṣàìsàn.
dialogue.translation: How is your body? I heard you are ill.

dialogue.speaker: Fúnmi
dialogue.text: Kò yá rárá. Mo ní ibà, ó sì ń dùn mí.
dialogue.translation: Not well at all. I have malaria and it hurts.

dialogue.speaker: Kúnlé
dialogue.text: Ẹ kú ìrora. Ṣé o ti lọ sí ilé ìwòsàn?
dialogue.translation: Sorry for your pain. Have you gone to the hospital?

dialogue.speaker: Fúnmi
dialogue.text: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, mo gba oògùn. Mo ní láti sinmi.
dialogue.translation: Yes, I got medicine. I need to rest.

dialogue.speaker: Kúnlé
dialogue.text: Sinmi dáadáa, kí o yára sàn.
dialogue.translation: Rest well, so you recover quickly.

culturalNotes.title: Health and Community
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba culture, illness is a community concern. People will visit, call, or send messages to check on the sick. It's important to acknowledge their concern with gratitude.

culturalNotes.title: Traditional vs. Modern Medicine
culturalNotes.content: Many Yoruba people use both traditional herbs (àgbo) and modern medicine. It's common to hear 'oògùn àbáláyé' (traditional medicine) alongside hospital prescriptions.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'How is your body?' in Yoruba?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Báwo ni ara rẹ?' directly asks about physical well‑being.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Mo ní ibà' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ibà' means malaria/fever.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I am tired'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ó rẹ̀ mí' expresses tiredness.

practiceExercises.question: Which phrase expresses sympathy for someone in pain?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ kú ìrora' is specifically for pain.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Ara mi ò yá', what do they mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ara mi ò yá' means 'my body is not well'.

tips: When your child is ill, use 'Báwo ni ara rẹ?' to check on them and teach these phrases.
If a friend is sick, send a message with 'Ẹ kú ìrora' – it shows you care.
In a professional setting, if a colleague is unwell, a polite 'Báwo ni ara rẹ?' is appropriate.
When your spouse is ill, these phrases help you express concern and care.
Knowing health phrases is vital when seeking medical help in Nigeria.
Combine health phrases with prayers: 'Ọlọ́run á sàn ọ́' (God heal you).
If you have a cough, you might say 'kọ́ọ́ ń mí' (cough is troubling me).

levels.title: Level 22: Questions
levels.description: Answering personal questions ('Are you married?' 'How many children?' 'Why are you not fat?'). Polite deflections and humour.
learningObjectives: Understand and respond to common personal questions

vocabulary.translation: Are you married? (lit. Do you have a wife?)
vocabulary.example: Ṣé o ti ní ìyàwó? – Rárá, ò tíì tó.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Direct question; it's common for elders to ask.

vocabulary.translation: How many children do you have?
vocabulary.example: Mélòó ní ọmọ? – Mo ní mẹ́ta.

vocabulary.word: Kí ló dé tí o ò fi sanra?
vocabulary.pronunciation: kee loh deh tee oh oh fee sahn-rah
vocabulary.example: Kí ló dé tí o ò fi sanra? – Àkúnlẹ̀bù mi ni.
vocabulary.culturalNote: In some cultures, being fat is seen as a sign of wealth/health, so this question is common, though it can be sensitive.

vocabulary.example: Ṣé o fẹ́ fẹ́? – Ọlọ́run ló mọ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: A humble way to avoid answering directly.

vocabulary.example: Ṣé o máa ní ọmọ? – Bó bá ṣe é.
Ṣé o fẹ́ fẹ́ ẹ? – Mo ṣì ń rò ó.
Kí ló dé tí o rí báyìí? – Ẹ̀yin ló dára!
vocabulary.culturalNote: Turn the question back as a compliment.

vocabulary.example: Ìrísí mi jẹ́ àkúnlẹ̀bù mi.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Used to explain one's lot in life.

vocabulary.translation: There's no reason / No particular reason
vocabulary.example: Kí ló dé tí o kọ́? – Kò sí ìdí.
Ṣé o fẹ́ fẹ́? – Rárá o, ò tíì tó.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'Ṣé' at the beginning to form yes/no questions.
examples: Ṣé o ti ní ọmọ? – Do you already have children?
Ṣé o lọ sí ìgbéyẹ́wó? – Did you go to the wedding?

grammarPoints.explanation: Use phrases like 'Ọlọ́run ló mọ̀' or 'Bó bá ṣe é' to politely avoid answering personal questions.
examples: Ṣé o máa fẹ́? – Ọlọ́run ló mọ̀.
Mélòó ní ọmọ? – Bó bá ṣe é.

dialogue.speaker: Ìyá àgbà (Elderly woman)
dialogue.text: Ọmọ mi, ṣé o ti ní ìyàwó?
dialogue.translation: My child, are you married?

dialogue.speaker: Ọmọ (Young person)
dialogue.text: Rárá o, ò tíì tó. Mo ṣì ń kọ́ iṣẹ́.
dialogue.translation: No, it's not yet time. I'm still learning a trade.

dialogue.speaker: Ìyá àgbà
dialogue.text: Ṣé o fẹ́ ọmọ? Mélòó?
dialogue.translation: Do you want children? How many?

dialogue.speaker: Ọmọ
dialogue.text: Ọlọ́run ló mọ̀. Bó bá ṣe é ni.
dialogue.translation: God knows. Whatever happens.

dialogue.speaker: Ìyá àgbà
dialogue.text: Kí ló dé tí o ò fi sanra? O ń jẹun dáadáa bí?
dialogue.translation: Why are you not fat? Do you eat well?

dialogue.speaker: Ọmọ
dialogue.text: Ẹ̀yin ló dára! Èmi kì í sanra rárá.
dialogue.translation: You are the one! I never get fat.

culturalNotes.title: Personal Questions as Interest
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba culture, asking personal questions like 'Are you married?' or 'Why are you not fat?' is often a sign of genuine interest and care, not nosiness. However, it's acceptable to deflect politely.

culturalNotes.title: Humour in Deflection
culturalNotes.content: Yoruba people often use humour and proverbs to avoid direct answers. A witty response can defuse tension and keep the conversation light.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'Are you married?' informally?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ṣé o ti ní ìyàwó?' is the common way to ask a man if he's married.

practiceExercises.question: What is a polite way to avoid answering a personal question?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọlọ́run ló mọ̀' (God knows) is a polite deflection.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'How many children do you have?'
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mélòó ní ọmọ?' is correct.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Bó bá ṣe é' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It's a flexible expression meaning 'if it is possible / God willing / maybe'.

practiceExercises.question: If someone asks why you are not fat, what can you say?
practiceExercises.explanation: Turning it into a compliment ('you are the one') is a humorous deflection.

tips: Teach children how to politely answer or deflect personal questions from elders.
When visiting Nigeria, be prepared for personal questions. Use these deflections to stay comfortable.
In business, if asked personal questions, a light deflection with humour maintains professionalism.
Spouses often get personal questions from family – practice these responses together.
If you're new, these deflections help you navigate social situations gracefully.
Smile when deflecting – it shows you're not offended.
Using 'Ọlọ́run ló mọ̀' is always a safe, respectful answer.

levels.title: Level 23: Preferences
levels.description: Expressing likes/dislikes: 'I love this,' 'I hate pepper,' 'I don’t like wahala.'
learningObjectives: Talk about preferences in food, activities, and situations

vocabulary.example: Mo nífẹ̀ẹ́ oúnjẹ Yorùbá.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Strong affection; can be used for people, food, things.

vocabulary.example: Mo fẹ́ràn orin fújì.
Mo kórìíra ata.

vocabulary.translation: I don't like it / It doesn't please me
vocabulary.example: Kò dùn mí bí wọ́n ṣe ṣe é.
N kò fẹ́ wahálà.
Mo fẹ́ràn láti kọ́ èdè.
Mo fẹ́ràn iṣu jù lọ.

vocabulary.translation: I can't stand / It's impossible for me
vocabulary.example: Kò ṣeé ṣe fún mi láti jẹ ata.
Yam dára ju dòdò.
Oúnjẹ tó ṣe pàtàkì fún mi ni àmàlà.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Fẹ́ràn' is more common for everyday likes; 'nífẹ̀ẹ́' is stronger, often used for love.
examples: Mo fẹ́ràn ọ̀gbẹ̀dẹ̀ – I like ogbono soup.
Mo nífẹ̀ẹ́ rẹ – I love you.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Kórìíra' is hate; 'kò dùn mí' is milder (it doesn't please me).
examples: Mo kórìíra ẹ̀gún – I hate bones.
Kò dùn mí láti lọ síbẹ̀ – I don't like going there.
grammarPoints.pattern: Subject + kórìíra + object / Kò dùn mí + láti + verb

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Ṣé o fẹ́ràn ẹ̀bà?
dialogue.translation: Do you like eba?

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, mo fẹ́ràn ẹ̀bà púpọ̀, àmọ́ mo kórìíra ẹ̀fọ́.
dialogue.translation: Yes, I like eba a lot, but I hate vegetables.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Kí ló dé tí o kórìíra ẹ̀fọ́?
dialogue.translation: Why do you hate vegetables?

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
