dialogue.text: Kò dùn mí, ó ń korò. Mo fẹ́ràn ata jù.
dialogue.translation: I don't like them, they're bitter. I prefer pepper.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Èmi náà fẹ́ràn ata, ṣùgbọ́n kò dùn mí tí ó bá pọ̀ jù.
dialogue.translation: I also like pepper, but I don't like it when it's too much.

culturalNotes.title: Food Preferences
culturalNotes.content: Food is central to Yoruba culture. Expressing likes and dislikes about food is common in conversations. 'Wàhálà' is often used to describe any bothersome situation, not just food.

culturalNotes.title: Politeness in Dislikes
culturalNotes.content: When offered food you don't like, it's polite to say 'Kò dùn mí' rather than 'Mo kórìíra', which is too strong. A gentle refusal is appreciated.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I like' (mild) in Yoruba?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo fẹ́ràn' is the common way to say 'I like'.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Mo kórìíra' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo kórìíra' means I hate.

practiceExercises.question: How do you express a mild dislike, like 'I don't like it'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kò dùn mí' is a mild way to say it doesn't please me.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'wàhálà' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Wàhálà' means trouble or stress.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I prefer yam'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Jù lọ' indicates preference: 'I like yam more'.

tips: Ask children what they like/dislike in Yoruba – it builds vocabulary and emotional expression.
Use these phrases to talk about your favorite music, food, or activities.
In meetings, you can say 'Kò dùn mí' to politely disagree with a proposal.
Share your preferences with your spouse – it helps in planning meals and activities.
When offered food, it's good to know how to politely refuse something you don't like.
Use 'púpọ̀' (very) to intensify: 'Mo fẹ́ràn púpọ̀'.
'Wàhálà' is a versatile word – you can say 'Má ṣe wàhálà' (don't cause trouble).

levels.title: Level 24: Gossip
levels.description: Small talk vocabulary: 'Did you hear?' 'Who told you?' 'Keep it between us.' Etiquette of secret‑keeping.
learningObjectives: Use phrases for sharing and receiving news

vocabulary.example: Ṣé o gbọ́ ohun tó ṣẹlẹ̀ lánàá?
Ta ló sọ fún ọ? – Ẹnìkan ló sọ.

vocabulary.word: Jẹ́ kí ó wà láàárín wa
vocabulary.translation: Let it be between us / Keep it between us
vocabulary.pronunciation: jeh kee oh wah lah-ah-reen wah
vocabulary.example: Jẹ́ kí ó wà láàárín wa, má sọ fún ẹlòmíì.
Má sọ fún ẹnikẹ́ni, àdìrẹ́ ni.
Ó jẹ́ àdìrẹ́ wa.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Also the name of a cloth; here it means secret.

vocabulary.example: Ó ṣẹlẹ̀ báyìí, jẹ́ kí n sọ fún ọ.
Ó jẹ́ òótọ́ pé ó fẹ́ fẹ́?

vocabulary.translation: This matter will not get out
vocabulary.example: Ọ̀rọ̀ yìí kò ní jáde lá ẹnu mi.

vocabulary.translation: Give me the scoop / Tell me
vocabulary.example: Gbé e fún mi, kí ló ṣẹlẹ̀?
vocabulary.audioContext: Informal way to ask for news

vocabulary.translation: My mouth will be sealed (I won't tell)
vocabulary.example: Ẹnu mi á dí, má ṣàníyàn.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'pé' to introduce reported statements or questions.
examples: Ó sọ pé ó lọ – He said that he went.
Ṣé o gbọ́ pé ó ṣẹlẹ̀? – Did you hear that it happened?

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'má' before a verb to form a negative command.
examples: Má sọ fún ẹnikẹ́ni – Don't tell anyone.
Má ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ – Don't do that.

dialogue.speaker: Kẹ́hìndé
dialogue.text: Ṣé o gbọ́ ohun tó ṣẹlẹ̀ lánàá?
dialogue.translation: Did you hear what happened yesterday?

dialogue.speaker: Táyé
dialogue.text: Rárá, kí ló ṣẹlẹ̀? Ta ló sọ fún ọ?
dialogue.translation: No, what happened? Who told you?

dialogue.speaker: Kẹ́hìndé
dialogue.text: Mo rí i lójú mi. Ṣùgbọ́n jẹ́ kí ó wà láàárín wa.
dialogue.translation: I saw it with my eyes. But let it stay between us.

dialogue.speaker: Táyé
dialogue.text: Ó dára, ẹnu mi á dí. Sọ fún mi.
dialogue.translation: Okay, my mouth is sealed. Tell me.

dialogue.speaker: Kẹ́hìndé
dialogue.text: Ó ṣẹlẹ̀ báyìí… Adé ti fẹ́ ìyàwó!
dialogue.translation: It happened like this… Ade has gotten married!

dialogue.speaker: Táyé
dialogue.text: Ó jẹ́ òótọ́? Ọlọ́run!
dialogue.translation: Is it true? Oh my God!

culturalNotes.title: Gossip as Social Bonding
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba culture, sharing news (gist) is a way to bond. However, there is an etiquette: secrets are respected, and betraying trust can damage relationships.

culturalNotes.title: The Role of Proverbs
culturalNotes.content: Gossip often includes proverbs to soften the message or add wisdom. For example, 'Ọ̀rọ̀ tí a bá sọ di àdìrẹ́' (a word spoken becomes a secret).

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'Did you hear?' in Yoruba?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ṣé o gbọ́?' is the common way to ask if someone heard news.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Jẹ́ kí ó wà láàárín wa' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It means 'let it be between us'.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'Who told you?'
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ta ló sọ fún ọ?' directly asks who told you.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'ẹnu mi á dí' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It's a metaphor for keeping a secret.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Don't tell anyone'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Má sọ fún ẹnikẹ́ni' is the correct negative command.

tips: Teach children the importance of keeping promises and not spreading harmful gossip.
When sharing juicy news, always add 'Jẹ́ kí ó wà láàárín wa' to show you trust the person.
In the workplace, be cautious with gossip. Use these phrases only with trusted colleagues.
Between spouses, secrets should be minimal, but these phrases can be used playfully.
Gossip is part of social life, but knowing how to politely ask for secrecy is key.
If you want to stress secrecy, say 'Àdìrẹ́ ni' (it's a secret).
Be careful: gossip can harm – use these phrases responsibly.

levels.title: Level 25: Mood
levels.description: Emotions: happiness, anger, sadness, confusion. 'I am annoyed,' 'Don’t worry me,' 'I am just laughing.'

vocabulary.example: Inú mi dùn láti rí ọ.
Má bínú, inú mi bí.

vocabulary.translation: I am sad / My heart is broken
vocabulary.example: Ọkàn mi bàjẹ́ nítorí ìrìn àjò rẹ.

vocabulary.translation: I am confused / It baffles me
vocabulary.example: Ọ̀rọ̀ tó sọ rú mi lójú.

vocabulary.translation: Don't worry me / Don't disturb me
vocabulary.example: Má ṣe dà mí nídèé, mo ń ṣiṣẹ́.
Mo ń rẹ́rìn-ín sí ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ.

vocabulary.translation: Keep laughing / You're joking (can be dismissive)
vocabulary.example: Ẹ máa rẹ́rìn-ín, òótọ́ ni.

vocabulary.translation: I am sorry / It pains me
vocabulary.example: Ó dùn mí láti gbọ́ ìròyìn náà.
Inú mi tì nítorí ìwà rẹ.
Kò sí ọ̀rọ̀, ẹ má ṣàníyàn.

grammarPoints.explanation: Many emotions use 'inú' (inside/stomach) or 'ọkàn' (heart).
examples: Inú mi dùn – I am happy.
Ọkàn mi bàjẹ́ – I am sad.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'má ṣe' + verb to tell someone not to do something emotional.
examples: Má ṣe bínú – Don't be angry.
Má ṣe dà mí nídèé – Don't disturb me.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Kí ló dé? Ojú rẹ kò dára.
dialogue.translation: What's wrong? Your face doesn't look good.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Inú mi bí. Ọ̀rọ̀ kan ṣẹlẹ̀ lónìí.
dialogue.translation: I am angry. Something happened today.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Má bínú, sọ fún mi kí n lè ràn ọ́.
dialogue.translation: Don't be angry, tell me so I can help.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Ó ṣeun, ṣùgbọ́n kò sí ọ̀rọ̀. Mo máa fi í sílẹ̀.
dialogue.translation: Thanks, but no problem. I'll let it go.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Inú mi dùn pé o sọ fún mi. Jẹ́ ká jẹun papọ̀.
dialogue.translation: I'm happy you told me. Let's eat together.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Ó dára, mo fẹ́ràn ìyẹn.
dialogue.translation: Okay, I'd like that.

culturalNotes.title: Expressing Emotions Openly
culturalNotes.content: Yoruba culture allows for open expression of emotions, but with restraint. Elders may mask anger with proverbs. It's important to read facial expressions and tone.

culturalNotes.title: Community Support
culturalNotes.content: When someone is sad or angry, community members often rally around, offering food, company, or advice. 'Kò sí ọ̀rọ̀' is a common phrase to calm someone.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I am happy'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Inú mi dùn' is happy.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Má ṣe dà mí nídèé' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It's a request not to be disturbed.

practiceExercises.question: How do you express anger?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Inú mi bí' means I am angry.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ó rú mi lójú' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It expresses confusion.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Kò sí ọ̀rọ̀', they mean:
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kò sí ọ̀rọ̀' is soothing.

tips: Help children name their emotions in Yoruba – it builds emotional intelligence.
Use these phrases to express how you feel on social media or with friends.
In the workplace, use 'Kò sí ọ̀rọ̀' to diffuse tension.
Express your emotions openly with your spouse using these phrases.
Understanding emotional expressions helps you connect with people.
Tone of voice matters – a happy 'inú mi dùn' sounds different from a sarcastic one.
If you're confused, you can also say 'ò yé mi' (I don't understand).

levels.title: Level 26: Invitation
levels.description: Inviting to parties, weddings, burials. Stating location, date, and the phrase 'Your presence is requested.'
learningObjectives: Use formal and informal invitation phrases

vocabulary.translation: We are inviting you / calling you
vocabulary.example: A ń pe ọ sí ayẹyẹ ìgbéyẹ́wó wa.
Ayẹyẹ ọjọ́ ìbí mi.
A ó ṣe ìgbéyẹ́wó ní October.
Ìsìnkú bàbá wa yóò wáyé lọ́la.
Ẹ wá gbádùn pẹ̀lú wa.
Ibùdó ayẹyẹ náà ni Ilé Ìṣẹ́lẹ̀.
Ọjọ́ kẹẹ̀ẹ́dógún oṣù kẹfà.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Dates are given in day-month order.

vocabulary.example: A ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ ní wákàtí kẹsàn-án òwúrọ̀.

vocabulary.translation: We want you to be present (formal)
vocabulary.example: A fẹ́ kí o wà ní ayẹyẹ wa.

vocabulary.translation: Come and grace us with your presence
vocabulary.example: Ẹ wá fi ọwọ́ pàdé ìgbéyẹ́wó wa.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Pe' means 'to call' or 'to invite'. Use 'ń pe' for ongoing invitation.
examples: A ń pe ọ sí ayẹyẹ – We are inviting you to the party.
Ó ń pe mí fún ìsìnkú – He is inviting me to the funeral.
grammarPoints.pattern: Subject + ń pe + object + sí + event

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'ní' before day/time, 'oṣù' for month, 'ọjọ́' for day of month.
examples: A ó ṣe é ní ọjọ́ kẹtàdínlógún oṣù kẹfà – We'll do it on the 17th of June.
Wákàtí méje ìrọ̀lẹ́ – 7pm.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Bísí, a ń pe ọ sí ayẹyẹ ọjọ́ ìbí wa.
dialogue.translation: Bisi, we are inviting you to our birthday party.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Ọpẹ́ o! Nígbà wo? Níbo?
dialogue.translation: Thank you! When? Where?

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Ní ọjọ́ kẹrìndínlógún oṣù keje, ní Ilé Ìgbìmọ̀, ní Ìkejà.
dialogue.translation: On the 14th of July, at the Community Hall, in Ikeja.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Wákàtí mélòó?
dialogue.translation: What time?

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: A ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ ní wákàtí kẹfà ìrọ̀lẹ́. Ẹ wá fi ọwọ́ pàdé.
dialogue.translation: We'll start at 6pm. Come grace us with your presence.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Mo máa wá, ó dàbọ̀.
dialogue.translation: I will come, goodbye.

culturalNotes.title: Invitation Etiquette
culturalNotes.content: Invitations to events like weddings and funerals are often extended verbally, by phone, or through printed cards. It's polite to respond promptly and attend if possible. If you cannot attend, a timely regret is appreciated.

culturalNotes.title: The Phrase 'Ẹ wá fi ọwọ́ pàdé'
culturalNotes.content: This formal phrase is used for important guests and shows deep respect. It literally means 'come and meet with your hand' – an honouring gesture.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'We are inviting you' informally?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'A ń pe ọ' is common and informal.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'ìsìnkú' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ìsìnkú' is funeral/burial.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'What time?'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Wákàtí mélòó?' asks for the time.

practiceExercises.question: What is the formal phrase for 'your presence is requested'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ wá fi ọwọ́ pàdé' is a very respectful invitation.

practiceExercises.question: If an invitation says 'Ní ọjọ́ kẹẹ̀ẹ́dógún oṣù kẹfà', when is it?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'ọjọ́ kẹẹ̀ẹ́dógún' is 15th; 'oṣù kẹfà' is June.

tips: Practice inviting family members to pretend events – it's fun and educational.
When inviting friends to your party, use 'A ń pe ọ' to sound cool and cultured.
For formal business events, use 'Ẹ wá fi ọwọ́ pàdé' in invitations to show respect.
When inviting in‑laws, a formal invitation phrase is appreciated.
If you're invited to an event, confirm the date and time to avoid 'Nigerian time' confusion.
Always confirm the venue and time when invited – they may change.
For funerals, use a somber tone when inviting.

levels.title: Level 27: Accept/Decline
levels.description: Saying 'Yes' enthusiastically. Saying 'No' without burning bridges: 'I will try,' 'God willing,' 'I am not around.'

vocabulary.example: Mo máa wá sí ayẹyẹ rẹ.
Dájúdájú màá wá.
Mo fẹ́ wá gan-an, mo dúpẹ́.
Bó bá ṣe é, màá wá.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Soft acceptance, not a firm promise.

vocabulary.example: Mo máa gbìyànjú láti wá.
Kò sí iyèméjì, màá wá.
Mi ò ní wà níbẹ̀ nítorí iṣẹ́.
Mi ò wà ní ìlú ní ọjọ́ yẹn.
Mo ní ìdílé mìíràn, mi ò lè wá.
Ẹ jọ̀wọ́, ó ṣeun, ṣùgbọ́n mi ò lè wá.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Máa' indicates future action.
examples: Màá wá – I will come.
Màá gbìyànjú – I will try.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'kò sí' (there is no) to soften negatives.
examples: Kò sí ìṣòro – There's no problem.
Kò sí ààyè – There's no space (can't attend).

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Ṣé o máa wá sí ayẹyẹ mi?
dialogue.translation: Will you come to my party?

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Dájúdájú! Mo fẹ́ wá gan-an. Kí ni ọjọ́?
dialogue.translation: Definitely! I really want to come. What date?

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Ọjọ́ kẹtàlá oṣù kejìlá.
dialogue.translation: 13th December.

dialogue.speaker: Kéhìndé (another friend)
dialogue.text: Adé, mi ò ní wà níbẹ̀, mo ní ìdílé mìíràn.
dialogue.translation: Ade, I won't be there, I have another commitment.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Kò burú, ó ṣeun fún ìdáhùn rẹ.
dialogue.translation: It's okay, thanks for your response.

dialogue.speaker: Kéhìndé
dialogue.text: Bó bá ṣe é, màá gbìyànjú fún ìpàdé mìíràn.
dialogue.translation: If possible, I'll try for another meeting.

culturalNotes.title: The Art of Polite Refusal
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba culture, direct refusal can be seen as rude. It's common to use softening phrases like 'bó bá ṣe é' (if possible) or give a reason like 'mi ò wà ní ìlú' (I'm not in town) to avoid hurting feelings.

culturalNotes.title: Enthusiasm in Acceptance
culturalNotes.content: When accepting, it's polite to show enthusiasm – 'Dájúdájú' or 'Mo fẹ́ wá gan-an' – to make the host feel valued.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I will come'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo máa wá' means I will come.

practiceExercises.question: What is an enthusiastic acceptance?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Dájúdájú' shows certainty and enthusiasm.

practiceExercises.question: How do you politely decline saying 'I have another commitment'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo ní ìdílé mìíràn' is a polite refusal.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Bó bá ṣe é' imply?
practiceExercises.explanation: It's a non‑committal, polite response.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Mi ò wà ní ìlú', what do they mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It's a common excuse for not attending.

tips: Teach children to respond to invitations politely, whether accepting or declining.
When you can't attend a friend's party, use 'Mo ní ìdílé mìíràn' – it's polite.
In business, if you can't attend a meeting, say 'Mi ò lè wá, mo ní ìdílé mìíràn' – it's professional.
When declining family invitations together, use 'we' forms: 'A kò lè wá'.
Learn these phrases to navigate the many invitations you'll receive.
Always thank the person for the invitation before declining.
If you say 'Bó bá ṣe é', follow up later if you can attend.

levels.title: Level 28: Compliments
levels.description: 'You look beautiful,' 'You are shining!' 'I love your fit.' Cultural note: avoid praising babies/objects without 'God bless.'
learningObjectives: Give compliments on appearance and possessions
Understand the cultural need to add 'God bless'

vocabulary.example: O rẹwà lónìí!
O ń tàn lónìí!
vocabulary.culturalNote: Often said to someone looking radiant.

vocabulary.example: Aṣọ rẹ dára gan-an.
Mo fẹ́ràn ìrísí rẹ lónìí.

vocabulary.translation: God bless it / May God bless (it)
vocabulary.example: Ọmọ rẹ dára, Ọlọ́run á bù kún un.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Always add this when praising a baby or object to ward off evil eye.

vocabulary.translation: May God protect it (said after praising)
vocabulary.example: Ilé rẹ lẹ́wà, kí Ọlọ́run pa á mọ́.
Mo dúpẹ́, ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ ṣe mí lójú.

vocabulary.translation: God did it / It's God's doing
vocabulary.example: Ọlọ́run ló ṣe é – response to 'you look good'.
O ṣeun fún ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ.

vocabulary.word: Kò sí ẹni tí ò nífẹ̀ẹ́ rẹ
vocabulary.pronunciation: koh see eh-nee tee oh nee-feh-eh reh
vocabulary.example: Kò sí ẹni tí ò nífẹ̀ẹ́ rẹ.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Rẹwà' is specifically for beauty; 'dára' is for good/nice.
examples: O rẹwà – You are beautiful.
Aṣọ rẹ dára – Your outfit is nice.

grammarPoints.explanation: After praising, add a blessing like 'Ọlọ́run á bù kún un' to prevent envy.
examples: Ọmọ rẹ dára, Ọlọ́run á bù kún un.
Ilé yìí lẹ́wà, kí Ọlọ́run pa á mọ́.

dialogue.speaker: Adùnní
dialogue.text: O rẹwà lónìí! Kí ni o wọ̀?
dialogue.translation: You are beautiful today! What are you wearing?

dialogue.speaker: Fúnmiláyọ̀
dialogue.text: Mo dúpẹ́. Aṣọ Ankára tuntun ni.
dialogue.translation: Thank you. It's a new Ankara dress.

dialogue.speaker: Adùnní
dialogue.text: Ó dára gan-an. Ọlọ́run á bù kún un.
dialogue.translation: It's very nice. God bless it.

dialogue.speaker: Fúnmiláyọ̀
dialogue.text: Àṣẹ, ẹ ṣé. Ìwọ náà ń tàn lónìí.
dialogue.translation: Amen, thank you. You are also shining today.

dialogue.speaker: Adùnní
dialogue.text: Ọlọ́run ló ṣe é.
dialogue.translation: God did it.

culturalNotes.title: The Evil Eye and Praise
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba culture, excessive praise without adding a protective blessing (like 'Ọlọ́run á bù kún un') is believed to attract envy or spiritual harm. This is especially important for babies, new cars, or new homes.

culturalNotes.title: Humble Responses
culturalNotes.content: When complimented, it's polite to deflect praise to God or thank the person without appearing proud. 'Ọlọ́run ló ṣe é' is a common humble response.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'You are beautiful'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'O rẹwà' directly says you are beautiful.

practiceExercises.question: What should you add after praising a baby?
practiceExercises.explanation: A blessing like 'God bless it' is essential.

practiceExercises.question: How do you respond humbly to a compliment?
practiceExercises.explanation: Both 'thank you' and 'God did it' are humble responses.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'O ń tàn' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It means you are glowing or shining.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Aṣọ rẹ dára', what are they complimenting?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Aṣọ' means clothing.

tips: Teach children to add 'Ọlọ́run á bù kún un' when they praise friends' toys or clothes.
When you compliment someone's new car or outfit, add the blessing – it shows cultural awareness.
In business, complimenting a colleague's presentation? Add 'Ọlọ́run á bù kún un' to show respect.
Compliment your spouse often, and add a blessing – it strengthens the bond.
If you admire a baby, always say 'Ọlọ́run á pa á mọ́' (God protect him/her).
When in doubt, add 'Ọlọ́run á bù kún un' after any praise.
Respond with a smile and 'Mo dúpẹ́'.

levels.title: Level 29: Condolences
levels.description: High‑stakes phrases: 'Be strong,' 'It is well,' 'Long life to you.'

vocabulary.translation: Sorry for your loss / May you have good heart
vocabulary.example: Ẹ kú ìnú rere lórí ẹni tó ṣaláìsí.
Ẹ kú ọ̀fọ̀, ẹ máa yára gbàdúrà.
Ẹ máa ṣe, Ọlọ́run kò ní fi yín sílẹ̀.

vocabulary.translation: It is enough / It is well (consolation)
vocabulary.example: Ó tó, ẹ má ṣàníyàn.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Implying the suffering is over for the deceased.

vocabulary.example: Ọlọ́run á tù yín lára nínú ìdààmú yìí.

vocabulary.word: Kí Ọlọ́run gba ọkàn rẹ̀ sí ibi ìsinmi
vocabulary.translation: May God receive his/her soul in rest
vocabulary.pronunciation: kee oh-loh-roon gbah oh-kahn reh see ee-bee ee-seen-mee
vocabulary.example: Kí Ọlọ́run gba ọkàn rẹ̀ sí ibi ìsinmi.
Ẹ jẹ́ kí a gbàdúrà fún ìdínà.

vocabulary.translation: It is peace / May peace be
vocabulary.example: Àlàáfíà ni fún òkú.

vocabulary.word: Ẹ jẹ́ kí a máa báa lọ
vocabulary.pronunciation: eh jeh kee ah mah bah-ah loh
vocabulary.example: Ẹ jẹ́ kí a máa báa lọ pẹ̀lú ìgbẹ́kẹ̀lé.

vocabulary.word: Ẹ jẹ́ kí a rántí wọn
vocabulary.pronunciation: eh jeh kee ah rahn-tee wohn
vocabulary.example: Ẹ jẹ́ kí a rántí iṣẹ́ rere wọn.

grammarPoints.explanation: As with greetings, 'kú' + noun is used for condolences.
examples: Ẹ kú ìnú rere – Condolences (lit. greetings for good heart).
Ẹ kú ọ̀fọ̀ – Greetings for bereavement.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'ẹ máa' + verb to encourage ongoing action.
examples: Ẹ máa ṣe – Be strong (lit. keep doing).
Ẹ máa gbàdúrà – Keep praying.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Mo gbọ́ ìròyìn ẹni tó ṣaláìsí. Ẹ kú ìnú rere.
dialogue.translation: I heard the news of the passing. My condolences.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí (bereaved)
dialogue.text: Mo dúpẹ́. Ó jẹ́ ìfẹ́ Ọlọ́run.
dialogue.translation: Thank you. It was God's will.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Ẹ máa ṣe, ẹ máa gbàdúrà. Ọlọ́run á tù yín lára.
dialogue.translation: Be strong, keep praying. God will comfort you.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Àṣẹ, a ó gbìyànjú. Ọlọ́run ló ní.
dialogue.translation: Amen, we will try. It is the Lord's.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Kí Ọlọ́run gba ọkàn rẹ̀ sí ibi ìsinmi.
dialogue.translation: May God receive his soul in rest.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Àṣẹ, ẹ ṣé púpọ̀.
dialogue.translation: Amen, thank you very much.

culturalNotes.title: Funeral Etiquette
culturalNotes.content: At Yoruba funerals, it's customary to dress in black or dark colours. Visitors sit with the family, offer condolences, and may stay for prayers and refreshments. It's a time for community support.

culturalNotes.title: Expressions of Faith
culturalNotes.content: Most condolences include references to God or faith. Phrases like 'Ó jẹ́ ìfẹ́ Ọlọ́run' (it was God's will) are common, reflecting deep religious beliefs.

practiceExercises.question: How do you offer condolences in Yoruba?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ kú ìnú rere' is a standard condolence.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ẹ máa ṣe' mean in a condolence context?
practiceExercises.explanation: It means 'be strong' or 'take heart'.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'God will comfort you'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọlọ́run á tù yín lára' is correct.

practiceExercises.question: What is the meaning of 'Kí Ọlọ́run gba ọkàn rẹ̀ sí ibi ìsinmi'?
options: May God receive his soul in rest
practiceExercises.explanation: It's a prayer for the deceased's soul.

practiceExercises.question: At a Yoruba funeral, what colour is typically worn?
practiceExercises.explanation: Black or dark colours are mourning colours.

tips: When a family friend loses a loved one, teach your children to say 'Ẹ kú ìnú rere'.
It's important to show up for friends during loss. Use these phrases to express support.
If a colleague experiences a bereavement, a sincere 'Ẹ kú ìnú rere' goes a long way.
When your spouse's family faces a loss, these phrases help you offer appropriate condolences.
Attending funerals is common; knowing these phrases shows respect.
Speak softly and sincerely when offering condolences.
Sometimes just sitting with the bereaved in silence is more powerful than words.

levels.title: Test 3
levels.description: Assessment: Role‑play – a friend is sad. Ask what’s wrong, listen, and offer appropriate comfort.
learningObjectives: Demonstrate comprehension of health, questions, preferences, gossip, mood, invitations, compliments, and condolences

practiceExercises.question: Your friend looks sad. How do you ask what's wrong?
options: Kí ló dé tí o rí báyìí?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kí ló dé tí o rí báyìí?' means 'Why do you look like this?' – appropriate for a sad friend.

practiceExercises.question: Your friend says 'Ọkàn mi bàjẹ́'. What does that mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọkàn mi bàjẹ́' means 'my heart is broken' – sadness.

practiceExercises.question: What comforting phrase can you offer?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ máa ṣe' (be strong) is a comforting encouragement.

practiceExercises.question: Your friend mentions they failed an exam. You want to say 'Don't worry, God will help you'. What do you say?
options: Má ṣàníyàn, Ọlọ́run á ràn ọ́ lọ́wọ́
practiceExercises.explanation: That phrase combines comfort and faith.

practiceExercises.question: After comforting, you want to change the mood by inviting them to eat. How do you say 'Let's eat together'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Jẹ́ ká jẹun papọ̀' is an inclusive invitation.

practiceExercises.question: Your friend accepts and thanks you. How do you respond?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kò tọ́pẹ́' is 'you're welcome'.

practiceExercises.question: What should you avoid doing when a friend is sad?
practiceExercises.explanation: Sometimes just listening is better than immediate solutions.

practiceExercises.question: If your friend says 'Mo kórìíra ayé', what emotion are they expressing?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo kórìíra ayé' means 'I hate the world' – anger/frustration.

practiceExercises.question: Which phrase shows you are offering condolences for a loss?
practiceExercises.explanation: That's a condolence phrase.

practiceExercises.question: After the conversation, your friend says 'Mo dúpẹ́ púpọ̀'. What do you say?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kò tọ́pẹ́' is the appropriate response to thanks.

tips: Role‑play this scenario with your child to build empathy and language skills.
Practice comforting a friend – it's a valuable life skill.
In the workplace, showing empathy to a stressed colleague builds trust.
Use these phrases to comfort your spouse during tough times.
Emotional support is highly valued – knowing these phrases helps you connect.
Review vocabulary from levels 21-29 before starting.
Take your time; empathy requires genuine feeling.
You can retry if needed.

levels.title: Level 21: Health
levels.description: Asking after someone’s health: 'How is your body?' 'I am tired,' 'I am coughing.' Empathy: 'Sorry for the pain.'
learningObjectives: Ask about someone's health and well‑being
Express sympathy for pain or illness

vocabulary.translation: How is your body? / How are you feeling?
vocabulary.example: Báwo ni ara rẹ? – Ara mi ò yá.
vocabulary.culturalNote: A common way to ask about someone's health, especially if they've been unwell.

vocabulary.example: Lẹ́yìn iṣẹ́ lónìí, ó rẹ̀ mí.
Mo ń wú kọ́ọ́ nítorí efúùfú.

vocabulary.translation: It hurts me / I am in pain
vocabulary.example: Orí mi ń dùn mí.
Mo ní ibà, mo ń wárìwì.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Malaria is very common; 'ibà' is fever/malaria.

vocabulary.example: Ẹ kú ìrora, ẹ máa yára gbàdúrà.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Said to someone suffering from pain or illness.

vocabulary.example: Mo dúpẹ́, ó dára báyìí.
vocabulary.culturalNote: A common response when asked about health.

vocabulary.example: Ara kò yá, ì bá sinmi.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Often used to explain absence or low energy.

vocabulary.translation: He/She has a fever (lit. it is hot)
vocabulary.example: Ọmọ náà ń gbóná, ó ní ibà.
Mú oògùn yìí, ì á sàn.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Mo ní' means 'I have' (illness, thing). 'Mo ń' + verb indicates ongoing action.
examples: Mo ní ibà – I have malaria.
Mo ń wú kọ́ọ́ – I am coughing.
grammarPoints.pattern: Subject + ní + noun / Subject + ń + verb

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'ẹ kú' + condition to express sympathy or acknowledge a state.
examples: Ẹ kú ìrora – Sorry for your pain.
Ẹ kú iṣẹ́ – Well done (acknowledging work).

dialogue.speaker: Kúnlé
dialogue.text: Báwo ni ara rẹ? Mo gbọ́ pé o ń ṣàìsàn.
dialogue.translation: How is your body? I heard you are ill.

dialogue.speaker: Fúnmi
dialogue.text: Kò yá rárá. Mo ní ibà, ó sì ń dùn mí.
dialogue.translation: Not well at all. I have malaria and it hurts.

dialogue.speaker: Kúnlé
dialogue.text: Ẹ kú ìrora. Ṣé o ti lọ sí ilé ìwòsàn?
dialogue.translation: Sorry for your pain. Have you gone to the hospital?

dialogue.speaker: Fúnmi
dialogue.text: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, mo gba oògùn. Mo ní láti sinmi.
dialogue.translation: Yes, I got medicine. I need to rest.

dialogue.speaker: Kúnlé
dialogue.text: Sinmi dáadáa, kí o yára sàn.
dialogue.translation: Rest well, so you recover quickly.

culturalNotes.title: Health and Community
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba culture, illness is a community concern. People will visit, call, or send messages to check on the sick. It's important to acknowledge their concern with gratitude.

culturalNotes.title: Traditional vs. Modern Medicine
culturalNotes.content: Many Yoruba people use both traditional herbs (àgbo) and modern medicine. It's common to hear 'oògùn àbáláyé' (traditional medicine) alongside hospital prescriptions.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'How is your body?' in Yoruba?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Báwo ni ara rẹ?' directly asks about physical well‑being.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Mo ní ibà' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ibà' means malaria/fever.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I am tired'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ó rẹ̀ mí' expresses tiredness.

practiceExercises.question: Which phrase expresses sympathy for someone in pain?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ kú ìrora' is specifically for pain.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Ara mi ò yá', what do they mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ara mi ò yá' means 'my body is not well'.

tips: When your child is ill, use 'Báwo ni ara rẹ?' to check on them and teach these phrases.
If a friend is sick, send a message with 'Ẹ kú ìrora' – it shows you care.
In a professional setting, if a colleague is unwell, a polite 'Báwo ni ara rẹ?' is appropriate.
When your spouse is ill, these phrases help you express concern and care.
Knowing health phrases is vital when seeking medical help in Nigeria.
Combine health phrases with prayers: 'Ọlọ́run á sàn ọ́' (God heal you).
If you have a cough, you might say 'kọ́ọ́ ń mí' (cough is troubling me).

levels.title: Level 22: Questions
levels.description: Answering personal questions ('Are you married?' 'How many children?' 'Why are you not fat?'). Polite deflections and humour.
learningObjectives: Understand and respond to common personal questions

vocabulary.translation: Are you married? (lit. Do you have a wife?)
vocabulary.example: Ṣé o ti ní ìyàwó? – Rárá, ò tíì tó.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Direct question; it's common for elders to ask.

vocabulary.translation: How many children do you have?
vocabulary.example: Mélòó ní ọmọ? – Mo ní mẹ́ta.

vocabulary.word: Kí ló dé tí o ò fi sanra?
vocabulary.pronunciation: kee loh deh tee oh oh fee sahn-rah
vocabulary.example: Kí ló dé tí o ò fi sanra? – Àkúnlẹ̀bù mi ni.
vocabulary.culturalNote: In some cultures, being fat is seen as a sign of wealth/health, so this question is common, though it can be sensitive.

vocabulary.example: Ṣé o fẹ́ fẹ́? – Ọlọ́run ló mọ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: A humble way to avoid answering directly.

vocabulary.example: Ṣé o máa ní ọmọ? – Bó bá ṣe é.
Ṣé o fẹ́ fẹ́ ẹ? – Mo ṣì ń rò ó.
Kí ló dé tí o rí báyìí? – Ẹ̀yin ló dára!
vocabulary.culturalNote: Turn the question back as a compliment.

vocabulary.example: Ìrísí mi jẹ́ àkúnlẹ̀bù mi.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Used to explain one's lot in life.

vocabulary.translation: There's no reason / No particular reason
vocabulary.example: Kí ló dé tí o kọ́? – Kò sí ìdí.
Ṣé o fẹ́ fẹ́? – Rárá o, ò tíì tó.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'Ṣé' at the beginning to form yes/no questions.
examples: Ṣé o ti ní ọmọ? – Do you already have children?
Ṣé o lọ sí ìgbéyẹ́wó? – Did you go to the wedding?

grammarPoints.explanation: Use phrases like 'Ọlọ́run ló mọ̀' or 'Bó bá ṣe é' to politely avoid answering personal questions.
examples: Ṣé o máa fẹ́? – Ọlọ́run ló mọ̀.
Mélòó ní ọmọ? – Bó bá ṣe é.

dialogue.speaker: Ìyá àgbà (Elderly woman)
dialogue.text: Ọmọ mi, ṣé o ti ní ìyàwó?
dialogue.translation: My child, are you married?

dialogue.speaker: Ọmọ (Young person)
dialogue.text: Rárá o, ò tíì tó. Mo ṣì ń kọ́ iṣẹ́.
dialogue.translation: No, it's not yet time. I'm still learning a trade.

dialogue.speaker: Ìyá àgbà
dialogue.text: Ṣé o fẹ́ ọmọ? Mélòó?
dialogue.translation: Do you want children? How many?

dialogue.speaker: Ọmọ
dialogue.text: Ọlọ́run ló mọ̀. Bó bá ṣe é ni.
dialogue.translation: God knows. Whatever happens.

dialogue.speaker: Ìyá àgbà
dialogue.text: Kí ló dé tí o ò fi sanra? O ń jẹun dáadáa bí?
dialogue.translation: Why are you not fat? Do you eat well?

dialogue.speaker: Ọmọ
dialogue.text: Ẹ̀yin ló dára! Èmi kì í sanra rárá.
dialogue.translation: You are the one! I never get fat.

culturalNotes.title: Personal Questions as Interest
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba culture, asking personal questions like 'Are you married?' or 'Why are you not fat?' is often a sign of genuine interest and care, not nosiness. However, it's acceptable to deflect politely.

culturalNotes.title: Humour in Deflection
culturalNotes.content: Yoruba people often use humour and proverbs to avoid direct answers. A witty response can defuse tension and keep the conversation light.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'Are you married?' informally?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ṣé o ti ní ìyàwó?' is the common way to ask a man if he's married.

practiceExercises.question: What is a polite way to avoid answering a personal question?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọlọ́run ló mọ̀' (God knows) is a polite deflection.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'How many children do you have?'
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mélòó ní ọmọ?' is correct.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Bó bá ṣe é' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It's a flexible expression meaning 'if it is possible / God willing / maybe'.

practiceExercises.question: If someone asks why you are not fat, what can you say?
practiceExercises.explanation: Turning it into a compliment ('you are the one') is a humorous deflection.

tips: Teach children how to politely answer or deflect personal questions from elders.
When visiting Nigeria, be prepared for personal questions. Use these deflections to stay comfortable.
In business, if asked personal questions, a light deflection with humour maintains professionalism.
Spouses often get personal questions from family – practice these responses together.
If you're new, these deflections help you navigate social situations gracefully.
Smile when deflecting – it shows you're not offended.
Using 'Ọlọ́run ló mọ̀' is always a safe, respectful answer.

levels.title: Level 23: Preferences
levels.description: Expressing likes/dislikes: 'I love this,' 'I hate pepper,' 'I don’t like wahala.'
learningObjectives: Talk about preferences in food, activities, and situations

vocabulary.example: Mo nífẹ̀ẹ́ oúnjẹ Yorùbá.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Strong affection; can be used for people, food, things.

vocabulary.example: Mo fẹ́ràn orin fújì.
Mo kórìíra ata.

vocabulary.translation: I don't like it / It doesn't please me
vocabulary.example: Kò dùn mí bí wọ́n ṣe ṣe é.
N kò fẹ́ wahálà.
Mo fẹ́ràn láti kọ́ èdè.
Mo fẹ́ràn iṣu jù lọ.

vocabulary.translation: I can't stand / It's impossible for me
vocabulary.example: Kò ṣeé ṣe fún mi láti jẹ ata.
Yam dára ju dòdò.
Oúnjẹ tó ṣe pàtàkì fún mi ni àmàlà.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Fẹ́ràn' is more common for everyday likes; 'nífẹ̀ẹ́' is stronger, often used for love.
examples: Mo fẹ́ràn ọ̀gbẹ̀dẹ̀ – I like ogbono soup.
Mo nífẹ̀ẹ́ rẹ – I love you.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Kórìíra' is hate; 'kò dùn mí' is milder (it doesn't please me).
examples: Mo kórìíra ẹ̀gún – I hate bones.
Kò dùn mí láti lọ síbẹ̀ – I don't like going there.
grammarPoints.pattern: Subject + kórìíra + object / Kò dùn mí + láti + verb

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Ṣé o fẹ́ràn ẹ̀bà?
dialogue.translation: Do you like eba?

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, mo fẹ́ràn ẹ̀bà púpọ̀, àmọ́ mo kórìíra ẹ̀fọ́.
dialogue.translation: Yes, I like eba a lot, but I hate vegetables.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Kí ló dé tí o kórìíra ẹ̀fọ́?
dialogue.translation: Why do you hate vegetables?

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Kò dùn mí, ó ń korò. Mo fẹ́ràn ata jù.
dialogue.translation: I don't like them, they're bitter. I prefer pepper.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Èmi náà fẹ́ràn ata, ṣùgbọ́n kò dùn mí tí ó bá pọ̀ jù.
dialogue.translation: I also like pepper, but I don't like it when it's too much.

culturalNotes.title: Food Preferences
culturalNotes.content: Food is central to Yoruba culture. Expressing likes and dislikes about food is common in conversations. 'Wàhálà' is often used to describe any bothersome situation, not just food.

culturalNotes.title: Politeness in Dislikes
culturalNotes.content: When offered food you don't like, it's polite to say 'Kò dùn mí' rather than 'Mo kórìíra', which is too strong. A gentle refusal is appreciated.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I like' (mild) in Yoruba?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo fẹ́ràn' is the common way to say 'I like'.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Mo kórìíra' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo kórìíra' means I hate.

practiceExercises.question: How do you express a mild dislike, like 'I don't like it'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kò dùn mí' is a mild way to say it doesn't please me.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'wàhálà' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Wàhálà' means trouble or stress.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I prefer yam'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Jù lọ' indicates preference: 'I like yam more'.

tips: Ask children what they like/dislike in Yoruba – it builds vocabulary and emotional expression.
Use these phrases to talk about your favorite music, food, or activities.
In meetings, you can say 'Kò dùn mí' to politely disagree with a proposal.
Share your preferences with your spouse – it helps in planning meals and activities.
When offered food, it's good to know how to politely refuse something you don't like.
Use 'púpọ̀' (very) to intensify: 'Mo fẹ́ràn púpọ̀'.
'Wàhálà' is a versatile word – you can say 'Má ṣe wàhálà' (don't cause trouble).

levels.title: Level 24: Gossip
levels.description: Small talk vocabulary: 'Did you hear?' 'Who told you?' 'Keep it between us.' Etiquette of secret‑keeping.
learningObjectives: Use phrases for sharing and receiving news

vocabulary.example: Ṣé o gbọ́ ohun tó ṣẹlẹ̀ lánàá?
Ta ló sọ fún ọ? – Ẹnìkan ló sọ.

vocabulary.word: Jẹ́ kí ó wà láàárín wa
vocabulary.translation: Let it be between us / Keep it between us
vocabulary.pronunciation: jeh kee oh wah lah-ah-reen wah
vocabulary.example: Jẹ́ kí ó wà láàárín wa, má sọ fún ẹlòmíì.
Má sọ fún ẹnikẹ́ni, àdìrẹ́ ni.
Ó jẹ́ àdìrẹ́ wa.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Also the name of a cloth; here it means secret.

vocabulary.example: Ó ṣẹlẹ̀ báyìí, jẹ́ kí n sọ fún ọ.
Ó jẹ́ òótọ́ pé ó fẹ́ fẹ́?

vocabulary.translation: This matter will not get out
vocabulary.example: Ọ̀rọ̀ yìí kò ní jáde lá ẹnu mi.

vocabulary.translation: Give me the scoop / Tell me
vocabulary.example: Gbé e fún mi, kí ló ṣẹlẹ̀?
vocabulary.audioContext: Informal way to ask for news

vocabulary.translation: My mouth will be sealed (I won't tell)
vocabulary.example: Ẹnu mi á dí, má ṣàníyàn.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'pé' to introduce reported statements or questions.
examples: Ó sọ pé ó lọ – He said that he went.
Ṣé o gbọ́ pé ó ṣẹlẹ̀? – Did you hear that it happened?

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'má' before a verb to form a negative command.
examples: Má sọ fún ẹnikẹ́ni – Don't tell anyone.
Má ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ – Don't do that.

dialogue.speaker: Kẹ́hìndé
dialogue.text: Ṣé o gbọ́ ohun tó ṣẹlẹ̀ lánàá?
dialogue.translation: Did you hear what happened yesterday?

dialogue.speaker: Táyé
dialogue.text: Rárá, kí ló ṣẹlẹ̀? Ta ló sọ fún ọ?
dialogue.translation: No, what happened? Who told you?

dialogue.speaker: Kẹ́hìndé
dialogue.text: Mo rí i lójú mi. Ṣùgbọ́n jẹ́ kí ó wà láàárín wa.
dialogue.translation: I saw it with my eyes. But let it stay between us.

dialogue.speaker: Táyé
dialogue.text: Ó dára, ẹnu mi á dí. Sọ fún mi.
dialogue.translation: Okay, my mouth is sealed. Tell me.

dialogue.speaker: Kẹ́hìndé
dialogue.text: Ó ṣẹlẹ̀ báyìí… Adé ti fẹ́ ìyàwó!
dialogue.translation: It happened like this… Ade has gotten married!

dialogue.speaker: Táyé
dialogue.text: Ó jẹ́ òótọ́? Ọlọ́run!
dialogue.translation: Is it true? Oh my God!

culturalNotes.title: Gossip as Social Bonding
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba culture, sharing news (gist) is a way to bond. However, there is an etiquette: secrets are respected, and betraying trust can damage relationships.

culturalNotes.title: The Role of Proverbs
culturalNotes.content: Gossip often includes proverbs to soften the message or add wisdom. For example, 'Ọ̀rọ̀ tí a bá sọ di àdìrẹ́' (a word spoken becomes a secret).

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'Did you hear?' in Yoruba?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ṣé o gbọ́?' is the common way to ask if someone heard news.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Jẹ́ kí ó wà láàárín wa' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It means 'let it be between us'.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'Who told you?'
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ta ló sọ fún ọ?' directly asks who told you.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'ẹnu mi á dí' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It's a metaphor for keeping a secret.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Don't tell anyone'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Má sọ fún ẹnikẹ́ni' is the correct negative command.

tips: Teach children the importance of keeping promises and not spreading harmful gossip.
When sharing juicy news, always add 'Jẹ́ kí ó wà láàárín wa' to show you trust the person.
In the workplace, be cautious with gossip. Use these phrases only with trusted colleagues.
Between spouses, secrets should be minimal, but these phrases can be used playfully.
Gossip is part of social life, but knowing how to politely ask for secrecy is key.
If you want to stress secrecy, say 'Àdìrẹ́ ni' (it's a secret).
Be careful: gossip can harm – use these phrases responsibly.

levels.title: Level 25: Mood
levels.description: Emotions: happiness, anger, sadness, confusion. 'I am annoyed,' 'Don’t worry me,' 'I am just laughing.'

vocabulary.example: Inú mi dùn láti rí ọ.
Má bínú, inú mi bí.

vocabulary.translation: I am sad / My heart is broken
vocabulary.example: Ọkàn mi bàjẹ́ nítorí ìrìn àjò rẹ.

vocabulary.translation: I am confused / It baffles me
vocabulary.example: Ọ̀rọ̀ tó sọ rú mi lójú.

vocabulary.translation: Don't worry me / Don't disturb me
vocabulary.example: Má ṣe dà mí nídèé, mo ń ṣiṣẹ́.
Mo ń rẹ́rìn-ín sí ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ.

vocabulary.translation: Keep laughing / You're joking (can be dismissive)
vocabulary.example: Ẹ máa rẹ́rìn-ín, òótọ́ ni.

vocabulary.translation: I am sorry / It pains me
vocabulary.example: Ó dùn mí láti gbọ́ ìròyìn náà.
Inú mi tì nítorí ìwà rẹ.
Kò sí ọ̀rọ̀, ẹ má ṣàníyàn.

grammarPoints.explanation: Many emotions use 'inú' (inside/stomach) or 'ọkàn' (heart).
examples: Inú mi dùn – I am happy.
Ọkàn mi bàjẹ́ – I am sad.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'má ṣe' + verb to tell someone not to do something emotional.
examples: Má ṣe bínú – Don't be angry.
Má ṣe dà mí nídèé – Don't disturb me.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Kí ló dé? Ojú rẹ kò dára.
dialogue.translation: What's wrong? Your face doesn't look good.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Inú mi bí. Ọ̀rọ̀ kan ṣẹlẹ̀ lónìí.
dialogue.translation: I am angry. Something happened today.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Má bínú, sọ fún mi kí n lè ràn ọ́.
dialogue.translation: Don't be angry, tell me so I can help.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Ó ṣeun, ṣùgbọ́n kò sí ọ̀rọ̀. Mo máa fi í sílẹ̀.
dialogue.translation: Thanks, but no problem. I'll let it go.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Inú mi dùn pé o sọ fún mi. Jẹ́ ká jẹun papọ̀.
dialogue.translation: I'm happy you told me. Let's eat together.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Ó dára, mo fẹ́ràn ìyẹn.
dialogue.translation: Okay, I'd like that.

culturalNotes.title: Expressing Emotions Openly
culturalNotes.content: Yoruba culture allows for open expression of emotions, but with restraint. Elders may mask anger with proverbs. It's important to read facial expressions and tone.

culturalNotes.title: Community Support
culturalNotes.content: When someone is sad or angry, community members often rally around, offering food, company, or advice. 'Kò sí ọ̀rọ̀' is a common phrase to calm someone.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I am happy'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Inú mi dùn' is happy.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Má ṣe dà mí nídèé' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It's a request not to be disturbed.

practiceExercises.question: How do you express anger?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Inú mi bí' means I am angry.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ó rú mi lójú' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It expresses confusion.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Kò sí ọ̀rọ̀', they mean:
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kò sí ọ̀rọ̀' is soothing.

tips: Help children name their emotions in Yoruba – it builds emotional intelligence.
Use these phrases to express how you feel on social media or with friends.
In the workplace, use 'Kò sí ọ̀rọ̀' to diffuse tension.
Express your emotions openly with your spouse using these phrases.
Understanding emotional expressions helps you connect with people.
Tone of voice matters – a happy 'inú mi dùn' sounds different from a sarcastic one.
If you're confused, you can also say 'ò yé mi' (I don't understand).

levels.title: Level 26: Invitation
levels.description: Inviting to parties, weddings, burials. Stating location, date, and the phrase 'Your presence is requested.'
learningObjectives: Use formal and informal invitation phrases

vocabulary.translation: We are inviting you / calling you
vocabulary.example: A ń pe ọ sí ayẹyẹ ìgbéyẹ́wó wa.
Ayẹyẹ ọjọ́ ìbí mi.
A ó ṣe ìgbéyẹ́wó ní October.
Ìsìnkú bàbá wa yóò wáyé lọ́la.
Ẹ wá gbádùn pẹ̀lú wa.
Ibùdó ayẹyẹ náà ni Ilé Ìṣẹ́lẹ̀.
Ọjọ́ kẹẹ̀ẹ́dógún oṣù kẹfà.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Dates are given in day-month order.

vocabulary.example: A ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ ní wákàtí kẹsàn-án òwúrọ̀.

vocabulary.translation: We want you to be present (formal)
vocabulary.example: A fẹ́ kí o wà ní ayẹyẹ wa.

vocabulary.translation: Come and grace us with your presence
vocabulary.example: Ẹ wá fi ọwọ́ pàdé ìgbéyẹ́wó wa.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Pe' means 'to call' or 'to invite'. Use 'ń pe' for ongoing invitation.
examples: A ń pe ọ sí ayẹyẹ – We are inviting you to the party.
Ó ń pe mí fún ìsìnkú – He is inviting me to the funeral.
grammarPoints.pattern: Subject + ń pe + object + sí + event

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'ní' before day/time, 'oṣù' for month, 'ọjọ́' for day of month.
examples: A ó ṣe é ní ọjọ́ kẹtàdínlógún oṣù kẹfà – We'll do it on the 17th of June.
Wákàtí méje ìrọ̀lẹ́ – 7pm.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Bísí, a ń pe ọ sí ayẹyẹ ọjọ́ ìbí wa.
dialogue.translation: Bisi, we are inviting you to our birthday party.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Ọpẹ́ o! Nígbà wo? Níbo?
dialogue.translation: Thank you! When? Where?

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Ní ọjọ́ kẹrìndínlógún oṣù keje, ní Ilé Ìgbìmọ̀, ní Ìkejà.
dialogue.translation: On the 14th of July, at the Community Hall, in Ikeja.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Wákàtí mélòó?
dialogue.translation: What time?

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: A ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ ní wákàtí kẹfà ìrọ̀lẹ́. Ẹ wá fi ọwọ́ pàdé.
dialogue.translation: We'll start at 6pm. Come grace us with your presence.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Mo máa wá, ó dàbọ̀.
dialogue.translation: I will come, goodbye.

culturalNotes.title: Invitation Etiquette
culturalNotes.content: Invitations to events like weddings and funerals are often extended verbally, by phone, or through printed cards. It's polite to respond promptly and attend if possible. If you cannot attend, a timely regret is appreciated.

culturalNotes.title: The Phrase 'Ẹ wá fi ọwọ́ pàdé'
culturalNotes.content: This formal phrase is used for important guests and shows deep respect. It literally means 'come and meet with your hand' – an honouring gesture.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'We are inviting you' informally?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'A ń pe ọ' is common and informal.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'ìsìnkú' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ìsìnkú' is funeral/burial.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'What time?'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Wákàtí mélòó?' asks for the time.

practiceExercises.question: What is the formal phrase for 'your presence is requested'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ wá fi ọwọ́ pàdé' is a very respectful invitation.

practiceExercises.question: If an invitation says 'Ní ọjọ́ kẹẹ̀ẹ́dógún oṣù kẹfà', when is it?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'ọjọ́ kẹẹ̀ẹ́dógún' is 15th; 'oṣù kẹfà' is June.

tips: Practice inviting family members to pretend events – it's fun and educational.
When inviting friends to your party, use 'A ń pe ọ' to sound cool and cultured.
For formal business events, use 'Ẹ wá fi ọwọ́ pàdé' in invitations to show respect.
When inviting in‑laws, a formal invitation phrase is appreciated.
If you're invited to an event, confirm the date and time to avoid 'Nigerian time' confusion.
Always confirm the venue and time when invited – they may change.
For funerals, use a somber tone when inviting.

levels.title: Level 27: Accept/Decline
levels.description: Saying 'Yes' enthusiastically. Saying 'No' without burning bridges: 'I will try,' 'God willing,' 'I am not around.'

vocabulary.example: Mo máa wá sí ayẹyẹ rẹ.
Dájúdájú màá wá.
Mo fẹ́ wá gan-an, mo dúpẹ́.
Bó bá ṣe é, màá wá.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Soft acceptance, not a firm promise.

vocabulary.example: Mo máa gbìyànjú láti wá.
Kò sí iyèméjì, màá wá.
Mi ò ní wà níbẹ̀ nítorí iṣẹ́.
Mi ò wà ní ìlú ní ọjọ́ yẹn.
Mo ní ìdílé mìíràn, mi ò lè wá.
Ẹ jọ̀wọ́, ó ṣeun, ṣùgbọ́n mi ò lè wá.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Máa' indicates future action.
examples: Màá wá – I will come.
Màá gbìyànjú – I will try.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'kò sí' (there is no) to soften negatives.
examples: Kò sí ìṣòro – There's no problem.
Kò sí ààyè – There's no space (can't attend).

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Ṣé o máa wá sí ayẹyẹ mi?
dialogue.translation: Will you come to my party?

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Dájúdájú! Mo fẹ́ wá gan-an. Kí ni ọjọ́?
dialogue.translation: Definitely! I really want to come. What date?

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Ọjọ́ kẹtàlá oṣù kejìlá.
dialogue.translation: 13th December.

dialogue.speaker: Kéhìndé (another friend)
dialogue.text: Adé, mi ò ní wà níbẹ̀, mo ní ìdílé mìíràn.
dialogue.translation: Ade, I won't be there, I have another commitment.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Kò burú, ó ṣeun fún ìdáhùn rẹ.
dialogue.translation: It's okay, thanks for your response.

dialogue.speaker: Kéhìndé
dialogue.text: Bó bá ṣe é, màá gbìyànjú fún ìpàdé mìíràn.
dialogue.translation: If possible, I'll try for another meeting.

culturalNotes.title: The Art of Polite Refusal
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba culture, direct refusal can be seen as rude. It's common to use softening phrases like 'bó bá ṣe é' (if possible) or give a reason like 'mi ò wà ní ìlú' (I'm not in town) to avoid hurting feelings.

culturalNotes.title: Enthusiasm in Acceptance
culturalNotes.content: When accepting, it's polite to show enthusiasm – 'Dájúdájú' or 'Mo fẹ́ wá gan-an' – to make the host feel valued.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I will come'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo máa wá' means I will come.

practiceExercises.question: What is an enthusiastic acceptance?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Dájúdájú' shows certainty and enthusiasm.

practiceExercises.question: How do you politely decline saying 'I have another commitment'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo ní ìdílé mìíràn' is a polite refusal.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Bó bá ṣe é' imply?
practiceExercises.explanation: It's a non‑committal, polite response.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Mi ò wà ní ìlú', what do they mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It's a common excuse for not attending.

tips: Teach children to respond to invitations politely, whether accepting or declining.
When you can't attend a friend's party, use 'Mo ní ìdílé mìíràn' – it's polite.
In business, if you can't attend a meeting, say 'Mi ò lè wá, mo ní ìdílé mìíràn' – it's professional.
When declining family invitations together, use 'we' forms: 'A kò lè wá'.
Learn these phrases to navigate the many invitations you'll receive.
Always thank the person for the invitation before declining.
If you say 'Bó bá ṣe é', follow up later if you can attend.

levels.title: Level 28: Compliments
levels.description: 'You look beautiful,' 'You are shining!' 'I love your fit.' Cultural note: avoid praising babies/objects without 'God bless.'
learningObjectives: Give compliments on appearance and possessions
Understand the cultural need to add 'God bless'

vocabulary.example: O rẹwà lónìí!
O ń tàn lónìí!
vocabulary.culturalNote: Often said to someone looking radiant.

vocabulary.example: Aṣọ rẹ dára gan-an.
Mo fẹ́ràn ìrísí rẹ lónìí.

vocabulary.translation: God bless it / May God bless (it)
vocabulary.example: Ọmọ rẹ dára, Ọlọ́run á bù kún un.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Always add this when praising a baby or object to ward off evil eye.

vocabulary.translation: May God protect it (said after praising)
vocabulary.example: Ilé rẹ lẹ́wà, kí Ọlọ́run pa á mọ́.
Mo dúpẹ́, ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ ṣe mí lójú.

vocabulary.translation: God did it / It's God's doing
vocabulary.example: Ọlọ́run ló ṣe é – response to 'you look good'.
O ṣeun fún ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ.

vocabulary.word: Kò sí ẹni tí ò nífẹ̀ẹ́ rẹ
vocabulary.pronunciation: koh see eh-nee tee oh nee-feh-eh reh
vocabulary.example: Kò sí ẹni tí ò nífẹ̀ẹ́ rẹ.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Rẹwà' is specifically for beauty; 'dára' is for good/nice.
examples: O rẹwà – You are beautiful.
Aṣọ rẹ dára – Your outfit is nice.

grammarPoints.explanation: After praising, add a blessing like 'Ọlọ́run á bù kún un' to prevent envy.
examples: Ọmọ rẹ dára, Ọlọ́run á bù kún un.
Ilé yìí lẹ́wà, kí Ọlọ́run pa á mọ́.

dialogue.speaker: Adùnní
dialogue.text: O rẹwà lónìí! Kí ni o wọ̀?
dialogue.translation: You are beautiful today! What are you wearing?

dialogue.speaker: Fúnmiláyọ̀
dialogue.text: Mo dúpẹ́. Aṣọ Ankára tuntun ni.
dialogue.translation: Thank you. It's a new Ankara dress.

dialogue.speaker: Adùnní
dialogue.text: Ó dára gan-an. Ọlọ́run á bù kún un.
dialogue.translation: It's very nice. God bless it.

dialogue.speaker: Fúnmiláyọ̀
dialogue.text: Àṣẹ, ẹ ṣé. Ìwọ náà ń tàn lónìí.
dialogue.translation: Amen, thank you. You are also shining today.

dialogue.speaker: Adùnní
dialogue.text: Ọlọ́run ló ṣe é.
dialogue.translation: God did it.

culturalNotes.title: The Evil Eye and Praise
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba culture, excessive praise without adding a protective blessing (like 'Ọlọ́run á bù kún un') is believed to attract envy or spiritual harm. This is especially important for babies, new cars, or new homes.

culturalNotes.title: Humble Responses
culturalNotes.content: When complimented, it's polite to deflect praise to God or thank the person without appearing proud. 'Ọlọ́run ló ṣe é' is a common humble response.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'You are beautiful'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'O rẹwà' directly says you are beautiful.

practiceExercises.question: What should you add after praising a baby?
practiceExercises.explanation: A blessing like 'God bless it' is essential.

practiceExercises.question: How do you respond humbly to a compliment?
practiceExercises.explanation: Both 'thank you' and 'God did it' are humble responses.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'O ń tàn' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It means you are glowing or shining.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Aṣọ rẹ dára', what are they complimenting?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Aṣọ' means clothing.

tips: Teach children to add 'Ọlọ́run á bù kún un' when they praise friends' toys or clothes.
When you compliment someone's new car or outfit, add the blessing – it shows cultural awareness.
In business, complimenting a colleague's presentation? Add 'Ọlọ́run á bù kún un' to show respect.
Compliment your spouse often, and add a blessing – it strengthens the bond.
If you admire a baby, always say 'Ọlọ́run á pa á mọ́' (God protect him/her).
When in doubt, add 'Ọlọ́run á bù kún un' after any praise.
Respond with a smile and 'Mo dúpẹ́'.

levels.title: Level 29: Condolences
levels.description: High‑stakes phrases: 'Be strong,' 'It is well,' 'Long life to you.'

vocabulary.translation: Sorry for your loss / May you have good heart
vocabulary.example: Ẹ kú ìnú rere lórí ẹni tó ṣaláìsí.
Ẹ kú ọ̀fọ̀, ẹ máa yára gbàdúrà.
Ẹ máa ṣe, Ọlọ́run kò ní fi yín sílẹ̀.

vocabulary.translation: It is enough / It is well (consolation)
vocabulary.example: Ó tó, ẹ má ṣàníyàn.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Implying the suffering is over for the deceased.

vocabulary.example: Ọlọ́run á tù yín lára nínú ìdààmú yìí.

vocabulary.word: Kí Ọlọ́run gba ọkàn rẹ̀ sí ibi ìsinmi
vocabulary.translation: May God receive his/her soul in rest
vocabulary.pronunciation: kee oh-loh-roon gbah oh-kahn reh see ee-bee ee-seen-mee
vocabulary.example: Kí Ọlọ́run gba ọkàn rẹ̀ sí ibi ìsinmi.
Ẹ jẹ́ kí a gbàdúrà fún ìdínà.

vocabulary.translation: It is peace / May peace be
vocabulary.example: Àlàáfíà ni fún òkú.

vocabulary.word: Ẹ jẹ́ kí a máa báa lọ
vocabulary.pronunciation: eh jeh kee ah mah bah-ah loh
vocabulary.example: Ẹ jẹ́ kí a máa báa lọ pẹ̀lú ìgbẹ́kẹ̀lé.

vocabulary.word: Ẹ jẹ́ kí a rántí wọn
vocabulary.pronunciation: eh jeh kee ah rahn-tee wohn
vocabulary.example: Ẹ jẹ́ kí a rántí iṣẹ́ rere wọn.

grammarPoints.explanation: As with greetings, 'kú' + noun is used for condolences.
examples: Ẹ kú ìnú rere – Condolences (lit. greetings for good heart).
Ẹ kú ọ̀fọ̀ – Greetings for bereavement.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'ẹ máa' + verb to encourage ongoing action.
examples: Ẹ máa ṣe – Be strong (lit. keep doing).
Ẹ máa gbàdúrà – Keep praying.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Mo gbọ́ ìròyìn ẹni tó ṣaláìsí. Ẹ kú ìnú rere.
dialogue.translation: I heard the news of the passing. My condolences.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí (bereaved)
dialogue.text: Mo dúpẹ́. Ó jẹ́ ìfẹ́ Ọlọ́run.
dialogue.translation: Thank you. It was God's will.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Ẹ máa ṣe, ẹ máa gbàdúrà. Ọlọ́run á tù yín lára.
dialogue.translation: Be strong, keep praying. God will comfort you.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Àṣẹ, a ó gbìyànjú. Ọlọ́run ló ní.
dialogue.translation: Amen, we will try. It is the Lord's.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Kí Ọlọ́run gba ọkàn rẹ̀ sí ibi ìsinmi.
dialogue.translation: May God receive his soul in rest.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Àṣẹ, ẹ ṣé púpọ̀.
dialogue.translation: Amen, thank you very much.

culturalNotes.title: Funeral Etiquette
culturalNotes.content: At Yoruba funerals, it's customary to dress in black or dark colours. Visitors sit with the family, offer condolences, and may stay for prayers and refreshments. It's a time for community support.

culturalNotes.title: Expressions of Faith
culturalNotes.content: Most condolences include references to God or faith. Phrases like 'Ó jẹ́ ìfẹ́ Ọlọ́run' (it was God's will) are common, reflecting deep religious beliefs.

practiceExercises.question: How do you offer condolences in Yoruba?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ kú ìnú rere' is a standard condolence.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ẹ máa ṣe' mean in a condolence context?
practiceExercises.explanation: It means 'be strong' or 'take heart'.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'God will comfort you'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọlọ́run á tù yín lára' is correct.

practiceExercises.question: What is the meaning of 'Kí Ọlọ́run gba ọkàn rẹ̀ sí ibi ìsinmi'?
options: May God receive his soul in rest
practiceExercises.explanation: It's a prayer for the deceased's soul.

practiceExercises.question: At a Yoruba funeral, what colour is typically worn?
practiceExercises.explanation: Black or dark colours are mourning colours.

tips: When a family friend loses a loved one, teach your children to say 'Ẹ kú ìnú rere'.
It's important to show up for friends during loss. Use these phrases to express support.
If a colleague experiences a bereavement, a sincere 'Ẹ kú ìnú rere' goes a long way.
When your spouse's family faces a loss, these phrases help you offer appropriate condolences.
Attending funerals is common; knowing these phrases shows respect.
Speak softly and sincerely when offering condolences.
Sometimes just sitting with the bereaved in silence is more powerful than words.

levels.title: Test 3
levels.description: Assessment: Role‑play – a friend is sad. Ask what’s wrong, listen, and offer appropriate comfort.
learningObjectives: Demonstrate comprehension of health, questions, preferences, gossip, mood, invitations, compliments, and condolences

practiceExercises.question: Your friend looks sad. How do you ask what's wrong?
options: Kí ló dé tí o rí báyìí?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kí ló dé tí o rí báyìí?' means 'Why do you look like this?' – appropriate for a sad friend.

practiceExercises.question: Your friend says 'Ọkàn mi bàjẹ́'. What does that mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọkàn mi bàjẹ́' means 'my heart is broken' – sadness.

practiceExercises.question: What comforting phrase can you offer?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ máa ṣe' (be strong) is a comforting encouragement.

practiceExercises.question: Your friend mentions they failed an exam. You want to say 'Don't worry, God will help you'. What do you say?
options: Má ṣàníyàn, Ọlọ́run á ràn ọ́ lọ́wọ́
practiceExercises.explanation: That phrase combines comfort and faith.

practiceExercises.question: After comforting, you want to change the mood by inviting them to eat. How do you say 'Let's eat together'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Jẹ́ ká jẹun papọ̀' is an inclusive invitation.

practiceExercises.question: Your friend accepts and thanks you. How do you respond?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kò tọ́pẹ́' is 'you're welcome'.

practiceExercises.question: What should you avoid doing when a friend is sad?
practiceExercises.explanation: Sometimes just listening is better than immediate solutions.

practiceExercises.question: If your friend says 'Mo kórìíra ayé', what emotion are they expressing?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo kórìíra ayé' means 'I hate the world' – anger/frustration.

practiceExercises.question: Which phrase shows you are offering condolences for a loss?
practiceExercises.explanation: That's a condolence phrase.

practiceExercises.question: After the conversation, your friend says 'Mo dúpẹ́ púpọ̀'. What do you say?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kò tọ́pẹ́' is the appropriate response to thanks.

tips: Role‑play this scenario with your child to build empathy and language skills.
Practice comforting a friend – it's a valuable life skill.
In the workplace, showing empathy to a stressed colleague builds trust.
Use these phrases to comfort your spouse during tough times.
Emotional support is highly valued – knowing these phrases helps you connect.
Review vocabulary from levels 21-29 before starting.
Take your time; empathy requires genuine feeling.
You can retry if needed.

levels.title: Level 41: Proverbs
levels.description: 'A child who washes his hands...' and 'The sun that shines...' – context, not just memorisation.
learningObjectives: Understand and use common Yoruba proverbs
Know the appropriate context for each proverb
Appreciate the wisdom embedded in proverbs

vocabulary.word: Ọmọ tó bá fọwọ́ wẹ̀, ó ń bá àgbà jẹun
vocabulary.translation: A child who washes his hands eats with elders
vocabulary.pronunciation: oh-moh toh bah foh-woh weh, oh n bah ah-gbah jay-oon
vocabulary.example: Kò sí ọmọ tó lè ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ láìlọ́wọ́ sílẹ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Encourages children to be well‑behaved and respectful to be included in important matters.

vocabulary.word: Ọ̀rọ̀ tí a bá fi ẹnu sọ, kì í fi apá ṣe é
vocabulary.translation: Words spoken by mouth cannot be taken back by hand
vocabulary.pronunciation: oh-roh tee ah bah fay eh-noo soh, kee ee fay ah-pah shay ay
vocabulary.example: Ṣọ́ra pẹ̀lú ọ̀rọ̀ ẹnu rẹ.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Teaches the importance of thinking before speaking.

vocabulary.word: Ìgbà tí ọ̀rọ̀ bá ti jáde, kì í padà wá sí ẹnu
vocabulary.translation: When a word has left, it doesn't return to the mouth
vocabulary.pronunciation: ee-gbah tee oh-roh bah tee jah-deh, kee ee pah-dah wah see eh-noo
vocabulary.example: Má sọ̀rọ̀ tí ò dára, ó ti jáde.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Similar to 'a word once spoken is like a broken egg – can't be undone'.

vocabulary.word: Ilé l'á ń wò kí a tó sọ ọmọ l'órúkọ
vocabulary.translation: We consider the family before naming a child
vocabulary.pronunciation: ee-leh lah n woh kee ah toh soh oh-moh loh-roo-koh
vocabulary.example: Ó ṣe pàtàkì láti mọ ìdílé.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Emphasises that a child's name reflects their heritage.

vocabulary.word: A kì í fi ẹsẹ̀ kan wo ilé ẹlòmíì, ká fi ẹsẹ̀ méjì wo tiwa
vocabulary.translation: We don't use one foot to enter another's house and two feet to enter ours
vocabulary.pronunciation: ah kee ee fay eh-seh kahn woh ee-leh eh-loh-mee-e, kah fay eh-seh meh-jee woh tee-wah
vocabulary.example: Ó ṣe pàtàkì láti ṣe ohun tí o fẹ́ kí wọ́n ṣe fún ọ.

vocabulary.word: Bí ẹṣin bá jà, ìyókù kó máa yẹ̀ wọ́n lójú
vocabulary.translation: If horses fight, the grass suffers
vocabulary.pronunciation: bee eh-shin bah jah, ee-yoh-koo koh mah yay wohn loh-joo
vocabulary.example: Ìjà láàárín àwọn aláṣẹ máa ń jẹ àwọn aráàlú lára.
vocabulary.culturalNote: When leaders fight, the common people suffer.

vocabulary.word: Ọlọ́run kì í ṣe é tán, ó máa ń ṣe é kù
vocabulary.translation: God's work is never finished; there is always more
vocabulary.pronunciation: oh-loh-roon kee ee shay ay tahn, oh mah n shay ay koo
vocabulary.example: Ẹ máa gbàdúrà, Ọlọ́run kò tíì parí.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Expresses that God's blessings are endless.

vocabulary.word: Àjànítì láwọ̀, ó ní kí á gbọ́n tán kí á tó sùn
vocabulary.translation: The bedbug says we should be wise before we sleep
vocabulary.pronunciation: ah-jah-nee-tee lah-woh, oh nee kee ah gbohn tahn kee ah toh soon
vocabulary.example: Ó kìlọ̀ fún wa pé ká máa ṣọ́ra.

vocabulary.word: Ẹnìkan kì í jẹ àkàrà tó gbóná
vocabulary.translation: No one eats hot bean cake alone
vocabulary.pronunciation: eh-nee-kahn kee ee jeh ah-kah-rah toh gboh-nah
vocabulary.example: Ẹ jẹ́ ká pínpín ohun tí a ní.

vocabulary.word: Àkíí yọ́nà ká tó sọ pé ọ̀rẹ́ ni
vocabulary.translation: We don't walk a path before calling someone a friend
vocabulary.pronunciation: ah-kee yoh-nah kah toh soh peh oh-reh nee
vocabulary.example: Ẹ fi àkókò mọ ẹnìkan kí ẹ tó gbà á gbọ́.

grammarPoints.explanation: Yoruba proverbs often use parallel structures and metaphorical language. They may begin with 'Bí...bá' (if) or use contrast.
examples: Bí ẹṣin bá jà, ìyókù kó máa yẹ̀ wọ́n lójú.
Ọmọ tó bá fọwọ́ wẹ̀, ó ń bá àgbà jẹun.
grammarPoints.pattern: Varies, but often conditional or cause‑and‑effect.

grammarPoints.concept: Use of 'kì í' for General Truths
grammarPoints.explanation: 'Kì í' is used to express general truths or things that are not done (negative habits).
examples: A kì í fi ẹsẹ̀ kan wo ilé ẹlòmíì – One does not enter another's house with one foot.
Ẹnìkan kì í jẹ àkàrà tó gbóná – No one eats hot akara alone.

dialogue.speaker: Bàbá (Father)
dialogue.text: Ọmọ mi, ṣé o mọ òwe tí ó sọ pé 'Ọmọ tó bá fọwọ́ wẹ̀, ó ń bá àgbà jẹun'?
dialogue.translation: My child, do you know the proverb that says 'A child who washes his hands eats with elders'?

dialogue.speaker: Ọmọ (Child)
dialogue.text: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, bàbá. Ó túmọ̀ sí pé ó yẹ kí n máa ṣe ohun rere.
dialogue.translation: Yes, father. It means I should do good things.

dialogue.speaker: Bàbá
dialogue.text: Òótọ́ ni. Tí o bá ń ṣe rere, àwọn àgbà á gbà ọ́.
dialogue.translation: True. If you do good, the elders will accept you.

dialogue.speaker: Ọmọ
dialogue.text: Bàbá, ẹ kọ́ mi ní òwe mìíràn.
dialogue.translation: Father, teach me another proverb.

dialogue.speaker: Bàbá
dialogue.text: Ó dára. 'Bí ẹṣin bá jà, ìyókù kó máa yẹ̀ wọ́n lójú.' Kí ló túmọ̀ sí?
dialogue.translation: Okay. 'If horses fight, the grass suffers.' What does it mean?

dialogue.speaker: Ọmọ
dialogue.text: Ó túmọ̀ sí pé tí àwọn ńlá bá ń jà, àwọn kéékèèké ló máa ń jìyà.
dialogue.translation: It means that when big people fight, the small ones suffer.

culturalNotes.title: Proverbs as Wisdom
culturalNotes.content: Yoruba proverbs (òwe) are considered the 'horses' of speech – if you lose a proverb, you lose the ability to convey deep wisdom. Elders use them to teach, correct, and advise.

culturalNotes.title: Context is Key
culturalNotes.content: Using a proverb in the wrong context can be embarrassing. It's important to learn not just the words but when and how to use them.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ọmọ tó bá fọwọ́ wẹ̀, ó ń bá àgbà jẹun' mean?
options: Children should eat with elders always
A well‑behaved child is accepted by elders
Washing hands is important before eating
practiceExercises.explanation: It means a respectful, well‑behaved child gets to participate in important matters.

practiceExercises.question: Which proverb warns about the consequences of leaders' conflicts?
options: Ilé l'á ń wò kí a tó sọ ọmọ l'órúkọ
Bí ẹṣin bá jà, ìyókù kó máa yẹ̀ wọ́n lójú
A kì í fi ẹsẹ̀ kan wo ilé ẹlòmíì
Ọlọ́run kì í ṣe é tán
practiceExercises.explanation: The horses fighting and grass suffering represents leaders fighting and people suffering.

practiceExercises.question: What is the meaning of 'A kì í fi ẹsẹ̀ kan wo ilé ẹlòmíì, ká fi ẹsẹ̀ méjì wo tiwa'?
practiceExercises.explanation: It teaches fairness and the golden rule.

practiceExercises.question: When should you use the proverb 'Ẹnìkan kì í jẹ àkàrà tó gbóná'?
practiceExercises.explanation: It encourages sharing, as no one eats hot akara alone.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'kì í' generally indicate in Yoruba proverbs?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'kì í' expresses what is generally not done or a universal truth.

tips: Teach children proverbs gradually, explaining the meaning and context.
Using proverbs correctly in conversation shows wisdom and cultural knowledge.
In negotiations, a well‑placed proverb can build rapport and show respect.
Proverbs can be used to gently advise your spouse without direct confrontation.
Elders will be impressed if you use proverbs appropriately.
Listen to how elders use proverbs in conversation.
Start with common proverbs and practice using them.

levels.title: Level 42: Complaint
levels.description: Express dissatisfaction without shouting: 'This thing is not correct,' 'I paid for service but...' Assertive, not aggressive.
learningObjectives: Describe problems with services or goods

vocabulary.translation: This thing is not correct / not right
vocabulary.example: Ohun yìí kò tọ́, mo sanwó fún un.
Mo sanwó, ṣùgbọ́n wọn ò ṣe iṣẹ́ náà.
Oúnjẹ yìí kò dára tó.

vocabulary.word: Mo ní ìròyìn kan fún yín
vocabulary.translation: I have a complaint (literally: news) for you
vocabulary.pronunciation: moh nee ee-roh-yin kahn foon yin
vocabulary.example: Mo ní ìròyìn kan fún yín nípa iṣẹ́ yìí.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Polite way to introduce a complaint.

vocabulary.example: Ẹ jọ̀wọ́, ẹ ṣe àtúnyẹ̀wò ohun tó ṣẹlẹ̀.
Mi ò ní ìtẹ́lọ́rùn pẹ̀lú iṣẹ́ náà.

vocabulary.word: Mo fẹ́ kí wọ́n ṣe àtúnṣe
vocabulary.translation: I want them to make a correction
vocabulary.pronunciation: moh feh kee wohn sheh ah-toon-sheh
vocabulary.example: Mo fẹ́ kí wọ́n ṣe àtúnṣe lójúkan náà.

vocabulary.word: Ó yẹ kí ó yí pa
vocabulary.pronunciation: oh yeh kee oh yee pah
vocabulary.example: Ọ̀rọ̀ yìí, ó yẹ kí ó yí pa.

vocabulary.word: Kò sí èrò tí ó wà
vocabulary.pronunciation: koh see eh-roh tee oh wah
vocabulary.example: Kò sí èrò tí ó wà nínú bí wọ́n ṣe ṣe é.

vocabulary.translation: I have the right to speak
vocabulary.example: Mo ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ohun tó ṣẹlẹ̀.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'kò' (not) with adjectives or verbs to express that something is not right.
examples: Kò dára – It's not good.
Kò tọ́ – It's not correct.
Kò tó – It's not enough.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'ẹ jọ̀wọ́, ẹ...' to politely request action, even in complaints.
examples: Ẹ jọ̀wọ́, ẹ ṣe àtúnṣe – Please make a correction.
Ẹ jọ̀wọ́, ẹ yí i pa – Please change it.

dialogue.speaker: Oníbàárà (Customer)
dialogue.text: Ẹ jọ̀wọ́, mo sanwó fún iṣẹ́ yìí, ṣùgbọ́n kò dára tó.
dialogue.translation: Please, I paid for this service, but it's not good enough.

dialogue.speaker: Alábàáṣiṣẹ́ (Worker)
dialogue.text: Ẹ mà bínú. Kí ni kò dára?
dialogue.translation: Don't be angry. What is not good?

dialogue.speaker: Oníbàárà
dialogue.text: Ohun yìí kò tọ́. Mo fẹ́ kí ẹ ṣe àtúnṣe.
dialogue.translation: This thing is not correct. I want you to correct it.

dialogue.speaker: Alábàáṣiṣẹ́
dialogue.text: Ó dára, a ó ṣe àtúnṣe. Ẹ jọ̀wọ́ ẹ dúró díẹ̀.
dialogue.translation: Okay, we will correct it. Please wait a moment.

dialogue.speaker: Oníbàárà
dialogue.text: Mo dúpẹ́. Ẹ jẹ́ kí ó dára ní àkókò yìí.
dialogue.translation: Thank you. Let it be good this time.

dialogue.speaker: Alábàáṣiṣẹ́
dialogue.text: Kò ní ṣẹlẹ̀ mọ́. A ó rí i pé ó dára.
dialogue.translation: It won't happen again. We'll ensure it's good.

culturalNotes.title: Complaining Respectfully
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba culture, direct confrontation is often avoided. Complaints are usually prefaced with 'ẹ jọ̀wọ́' and expressed calmly to maintain harmony and respect.

culturalNotes.title: Saving Face
culturalNotes.content: When complaining, it's important to allow the other person to 'save face' by giving them a chance to correct the mistake without feeling publicly shamed.

practiceExercises.question: How do you politely say 'This thing is not correct'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kò tọ́' means 'not correct' and is assertive but polite.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Mo ní ìròyìn kan fún yín' imply in a complaint context?
options: I have news for you (a complaint)
I have a gift for you
practiceExercises.explanation: It's a polite way to introduce a complaint.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I am not satisfied'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mi ò ní ìtẹ́lọ́rùn' expresses dissatisfaction.

practiceExercises.question: If you want them to make a correction, you say:
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ṣe àtúnṣe' means 'make a correction'.

practiceExercises.question: What is the appropriate tone for a complaint in Yoruba culture?
practiceExercises.explanation: Calm and polite, with 'ẹ jọ̀wọ́', is the cultural norm.

tips: Teach children to express dissatisfaction politely without shouting.
When returning a faulty item, use these phrases calmly.
In business, a polite complaint maintains professional relationships.
Express your concerns to your spouse using 'Mo ní ìròyìn kan fún ọ' to soften the message.
If you receive poor service, a polite but firm complaint is more effective than anger.
Always start with 'ẹ jọ̀wọ́'.
State the problem clearly, then suggest a resolution.

levels.title: Level 43: Slang
levels.description: Current youth slang: 'Ajebo,' 'Omo,' 'Gbese,' 'Jaiye.' Warning: when not to use these.
learningObjectives: Understand common Yoruba and Nigerian slang
Use slang appropriately in informal contexts

vocabulary.translation: Bourgeois / Privileged / Someone who grew up with a silver spoon
vocabulary.example: Ó jẹ́ ajebo, kò mọ iṣẹ́ àṣekágbá.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Can be used playfully or derogatorily; be careful.

vocabulary.example: Omo yẹn wúlò gan-an.

vocabulary.translation: Debt / To owe / Also slang for 'to be in trouble'
vocabulary.example: Ó gbese, ó ní owó.
Ẹ jẹ́ ká jaiye pẹ̀lú àwọn ọ̀rẹ́.
Wahala ti dé o!
Yawa gbá!
Ó shepeteri gbogbo nǹkan.
Mo kpai pẹ̀lú ẹ̀rín.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Often used hyperbolically: 'I'm dying of laughter'.

vocabulary.example: Ó lọ sí Jand.
vocabulary.culturalNote: From 'Germany', but means any Western country.

vocabulary.translation: Local gin / Also slang for something strong
vocabulary.example: Àmọ̀tẹ́kùn yìí le.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Slang can also refer to strong alcohol.

grammarPoints.explanation: Many slang words come from English, Hausa, or Pidgin, and are integrated into Yoruba sentences.
examples: Ó lọ sí Jand – He went abroad.
Wahala ti dé – Trouble has come.
grammarPoints.pattern: Slang words often replace standard terms in informal speech.

grammarPoints.explanation: Slang often uses exaggeration, like 'kpai' (die) to mean extreme emotion.
examples: Mo kpai pẹ̀lú ẹ̀rín – I died of laughter.
Yawa gbá – Big trouble.

dialogue.speaker: Táyé (Youth)
dialogue.text: Omo, ṣé o gbọ́ ohun tó ṣẹlẹ̀? Yawa gbá!
dialogue.translation: Guy, did you hear what happened? Big trouble!

dialogue.speaker: Kẹ́hìndé (Youth)
dialogue.text: Kí ló ṣẹlẹ̀? Sọ fún mi, má jẹ́ kí n kpai pẹ̀lú ìyàlẹ́nu.
dialogue.translation: What happened? Tell me, don't let me die of curiosity.

dialogue.speaker: Táyé
dialogue.text: Ajebo tó ń gbé ìlú yẹn, ó gbese, ó sì shepeteri gbogbo nǹkan.
dialogue.translation: That privileged guy living in town, he owes money and messed everything up.

dialogue.speaker: Kẹ́hìndé
dialogue.text: Kò burú, ẹ jẹ́ ká jaiye, má fi wahala wọlé.
dialogue.translation: No problem, let's enjoy life, don't bring trouble home.

dialogue.speaker: Táyé
dialogue.text: Ó dára, jẹ́ ká lọ jẹun, mo fẹ́ ṣe bí ajebo fúngbà díẹ̀!
dialogue.translation: Okay, let's go eat, I want to live like a privileged person for a while!

dialogue.speaker: Kẹ́hìndé
dialogue.text: Lọ́jọ́ kan lọ́jọ́ kan, ṣùgbọ́n kí o má ṣe gbàgbé pé ọmọ ìtàkùn ni wá.
dialogue.translation: One day at a time, but don't forget we are grassroots people.

culturalNotes.title: Slang and Identity
culturalNotes.content: Slang is dynamic and often marks group identity. Youth use it to signal belonging. However, using slang in formal settings or with elders can be seen as disrespectful.

culturalNotes.title: Borrowed Slang
