culturalNotes.content: Many slang terms are borrowed from English, Pidgin, or other Nigerian languages. 'Wahala' (Hausa) and 'Jand' (from 'Germany') are examples of this cross‑pollination.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'ajebo' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ajebo' refers to someone from a privileged background.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'big trouble' in slang?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Yawa gbá' means big commotion/trouble.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'jaiye' encourage someone to do?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Jaiye' is about having fun and enjoying life.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Mo kpai pẹ̀lú ẹ̀rín', what do they mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kpai' is hyperbolic slang for 'die' – so 'dying of laughter'.

practiceExercises.question: When should you avoid using slang?
options: With elders or in formal settings
practiceExercises.explanation: Slang can be disrespectful with elders or in formal contexts.

tips: Understand your children's slang to stay connected, but teach them when it's appropriate.
Slang is fun, but know your audience – don't use it with elders or in formal settings.
Avoid slang in professional environments; it can seem unprofessional.
Playful slang between spouses can be fun, but be respectful when discussing serious matters.
Learning slang helps you connect with youth, but use it carefully.
Listen to how locals use slang before trying it yourself.
When in doubt, err on the side of formality.

levels.title: Level 44: Humor
levels.description: Simple jokes, wordplay, and how to laugh at yourself.

vocabulary.example: Sọ àwàdà kan fún wa.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Jokes are a big part of social life.

vocabulary.example: Ẹ̀rín ṣe pàtàkì.
Ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ yọyọ́ gan-an.
Ó ṣe pàtàkì láti fi ara rẹ ṣẹ̀rín.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Being able to laugh at yourself is a sign of humility.

vocabulary.example: Ó fi àpèjúwe sọ̀rọ̀.
Ọkùnrin kan wọ ọkọ̀... Kí ló ṣẹlẹ̀?
vocabulary.culturalNote: Standard way to start a joke.

vocabulary.example: Ọ̀gbọ́n ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ mú mi rẹ́rìn-ín.
O lọ? Kọ́, mo dúró.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Can be used for comic effect.

vocabulary.example: Wàhálà ti dé o! (said with a smile)
vocabulary.culturalNote: Even trouble can be joked about.

vocabulary.example: Ẹ máa rẹ́rìn-ín, ìlera ni.

grammarPoints.explanation: Yoruba humor often uses words with multiple meanings (homophones). For example, 'ọkọ̀' can mean vehicle or husband, leading to puns.
examples: Ọkọ̀ mi lọ – My vehicle left / My husband left.
Ó gbé 'ọkọ̀' mi – He took my vehicle / He took my husband.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use of 'púpọ̀' (plenty) or 'gan-an' (very) to exaggerate for comic effect.
examples: Ó pọ̀ tó bẹ́ẹ̀ tí... – It was so much that...
Mo rẹ̀ mí tó bẹ́ẹ̀ tí mo fẹ́ sùn fún ọdún – I was so tired I wanted to sleep for a year.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Sọ àwàdà kan fún mi.
dialogue.translation: Tell me a joke.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Ọkùnrin kan wọ ọkọ̀, ó ní 'Ọkọ̀ yìí máa lọ síbì kan?' Awakọ̀ ní 'Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, ẹ wọ̀.' Lẹ́yìn ìgbà díẹ̀, ọkùnrin náà ní 'Ṣé a ti débẹ̀?' Awakọ̀ ní 'Kò tíì, ṣùgbọ́n a sún mọ́!
dialogue.translation: A man entered a vehicle, he said 'Is this vehicle going somewhere?' The driver said 'Yes, enter.' After a while, the man said 'Are we there yet?' The driver said 'Not yet, but we are getting close!'

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Kí ló ṣẹlẹ̀ lẹ́yìn náà?
dialogue.translation: What happened after that?

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Awakọ̀ ní 'Kò sí tó bẹ́ẹ̀, àmọ́ ọkùnrin náà ti sùn!'
dialogue.translation: The driver said 'Nothing much, but the man had fallen asleep!'

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: LOL! Ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ yọyọ́ gan-an.
dialogue.translation: LOL! Your story is very funny.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Ẹ̀rín ní òògùn ìlera.
dialogue.translation: Laughter is medicine for health.

culturalNotes.title: Humor in Daily Life
culturalNotes.content: Yoruba people value humor and wit. Even in serious situations, a well‑timed joke can ease tension. Storytelling and jokes are passed down orally.

culturalNotes.title: Self‑Deprecating Humor
culturalNotes.content: Laughing at oneself is a sign of humility and confidence. It's common to hear someone say 'Mo fi ara mi ṣẹ̀rín' (I laughed at myself).

practiceExercises.question: What does 'àwàdà' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Àwàdà' is a joke.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'laugh at yourself'?
practiceExercises.explanation: Both 'fi ara rẹ ṣẹ̀rín' and 'rẹ́rìn-ín sí ara rẹ' mean to laugh at yourself.

practiceExercises.question: What is a common source of wordplay in Yoruba jokes?
practiceExercises.explanation: Words like 'ọkọ̀' (vehicle/husband) create puns.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Ó pọ̀ tó bẹ́ẹ̀ tí...', what are they doing?
practiceExercises.explanation: They are starting an exaggeration.

practiceExercises.question: Why is laughter considered 'òògùn ìlera'?
practiceExercises.explanation: Laughter is seen as beneficial to health.

tips: Share jokes with your children – it builds bonds and language skills.
A good sense of humor makes you popular. Learn to tell jokes in Yoruba.
Appropriate humor in the workplace can reduce stress, but know your audience.
Laughing together strengthens marriage. Share jokes with your spouse.
If you can laugh at yourself, you'll fit right in.
Listen to Yoruba comedians to understand humor.
Practice telling simple jokes.

levels.title: Level 45: Celebration
levels.description: Vocabulary for weddings, birthdays, title‑taking: 'I bring lafun,' 'Join the spray,' 'Mama, dance!'

vocabulary.example: Ayẹyẹ ọjọ́ ìbí mi.
A lọ sí ìgbéyẹ́wó ẹ̀gbọ́n mi.
Wọ́n ṣe ìsọmọlórúkọ fún ọmọ náà.
Bàbá mi gba ìjóyè ní ìlú.

vocabulary.translation: I bring lafun (camwood powder) – a traditional gift
vocabulary.example: Mo mú lafun wá fún ayẹyẹ náà.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Lafun (camwood) is used in blessings and as a gift.

vocabulary.example: Ẹ wá dá owó sí i fún ìyàwó.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Spraying money on celebrants is common at parties.

vocabulary.example: Màmá, jó! A ó rí ọ.
Àlùjó ìgbéyẹ́wó dùn.
Mo mú ẹ̀bùn wá fún ọmọ tuntun.
Àwọn àgbà ń sọ ìbùkún.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'fún' to indicate the purpose or recipient of an action.
examples: Mo mú lafun wá fún ayẹyẹ – I brought lafun for the celebration.
Wọ́n ṣe ìsọmọlórúkọ fún ọmọ – They held a naming ceremony for the child.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use imperatives like 'jó!' (dance!), 'dá owó sí i!' (spray money!) to encourage participation.
examples: Màmá, jó!
Ẹ wá dá owó sí i!

dialogue.speaker: Adé (Guest)
dialogue.text: Ayẹyẹ yìí dára gan-an! Ẹ jọ̀wọ́, ẹ jẹ́ kí n dá owó sí i fún ìyàwó.
dialogue.translation: This celebration is very nice! Please, let me spray money on the bride.

dialogue.speaker: Aláyẹyẹ (Host)
dialogue.text: Ẹ ṣé, ẹ wá! Ẹ wá fi ọwọ́ yín ṣe.
dialogue.translation: Thank you, come! Come and do it with your hands.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Màmá ìyàwó, ẹ wá jó pẹ̀lú wa!
dialogue.translation: Mother of the bride, come and dance with us!

dialogue.speaker: Màmá ìyàwó
dialogue.text: Mo ń bọ̀, mo ń bọ̀! Ẹ jẹ́ kí n gba ìbùkún lẹ́ẹ̀kọ̀ọ́kan.
dialogue.translation: I'm coming, I'm coming! Let me receive blessings one by one.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Mo mú lafun wá fún yín, gbà á.
dialogue.translation: I brought lafun for you, accept it.

dialogue.speaker: Màmá ìyàwó
dialogue.text: Ọlọ́run á bù kún un yín. Ẹ ṣé púpọ̀.
dialogue.translation: God bless you. Thank you very much.

culturalNotes.title: Spraying Money
culturalNotes.content: At Nigerian parties, guests often 'spray' money on celebrants by placing it on their foreheads or throwing it. It's a sign of appreciation and celebration. The celebrant's associates may pick up the money.

culturalNotes.title: Lafun (Camwood)
culturalNotes.content: Lafun is a red powder made from wood, used in traditional ceremonies to bless and anoint people. It's a symbolic gift.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I bring lafun' as a gift?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo mú lafun wá' means 'I brought lafun'.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'dá owó sí i' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It means to spray money at a celebration.

practiceExercises.question: How do you encourage someone to dance?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Jó!' means 'Dance!'

practiceExercises.question: What is a 'ìjóyè' ceremony?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ìjóyè' is the taking of a chieftaincy title.

practiceExercises.question: What do elders give at celebrations?
practiceExercises.explanation: Elders give blessings.

tips: Take children to celebrations and teach them the appropriate phrases.
At parties, use 'Mo fẹ́ dá owó sí i' if you want to spray.
If invited to a traditional ceremony, knowing these phrases shows respect.
You'll use these phrases at your own or others' weddings.
Celebrations are frequent – learn to participate fully.
If you're unsure, follow what others do.
When receiving a gift, say 'Ọlọ́run á bù kún un yín'.

levels.title: Level 46: Tradition
levels.description: Explaining cultural norms: 'In the past we did X, but now we do Y.'

vocabulary.example: Ṣáájú, wọ́n ń ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Used to contrast past and present.

vocabulary.example: Nísìnyí, wọ́n ti yí i pa.
Àṣà Yorùbá lágbára.
Ìṣe àwọn bàbá ńlá ni.
Àtijọ́, wọ́n ń gbé inú igbó.
Òde-òní, nǹkan ti yí.
Àṣà ti yí pa díẹ̀díẹ̀.
Bàbá ńlá wa ń ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.
Wọ́n ń kọ́ wa ní ẹ̀kọ́ ìbílẹ̀.
Ìgbàgbọ́ àtijọ́ yàtọ̀ sí ti òde-òní.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'ṣáájú' (before) and 'nísìnyí' (now) to contrast past and present practices.
examples: Ṣáájú, wọ́n ń ṣe ìsìnkú fún ọ̀sẹ̀ méje. Nísìnyí, wọ́n ń ṣe fún ọjọ́ mélòó kan.
Àtijọ́, àwọn ọmọ ń tọ́ bàbá ńlá. Nísìnyí, nǹkan ti yí.
grammarPoints.pattern: Ṣáájú/Àtijọ́ + past practice. Nísìnyí/Òde-òní + present practice.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'ti yí pa' (has changed) to indicate that something is different now.
examples: Àṣà ti yí pa – Tradition has changed.
Ìṣe wọn ti yí pa – Their practice has changed.

dialogue.speaker: Ẹ̀gbọ́n (Older)
dialogue.text: Ṣáájú, àwọn ọmọ máa ń tẹríba fún àgbà.
dialogue.translation: Before, children used to prostrate for elders.

dialogue.speaker: Àbúrò (Younger)
dialogue.text: Nísìnyí, wọ́n ṣì ń ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ ní díẹ̀, ṣùgbọ́n kò pọ̀ mọ́.
dialogue.translation: Now, they still do it in some places, but not much anymore.

dialogue.speaker: Ẹ̀gbọ́n
dialogue.text: Àtijọ́, a kì í jẹun láì fi ọwọ́ wẹ̀. Nísìnyí, wọ́n ti gbàgbé.
dialogue.translation: In the past, we didn't eat without washing hands. Now, they have forgotten.

dialogue.speaker: Àbúrò
dialogue.text: Òótọ́ ni, ṣùgbọ́n ẹ̀kọ́ ìbílẹ̀ ṣì wà lọ́wọ́.
dialogue.translation: True, but traditional education still exists.

dialogue.speaker: Ẹ̀gbọ́n
dialogue.text: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, a gbọ́dọ̀ máa tọ́jú àṣà wa.
dialogue.translation: Yes, we must preserve our culture.

dialogue.speaker: Àbúrò
dialogue.text: A ó gbìyànjú, ẹ̀gbọ́n.
dialogue.translation: We will try, elder.

culturalNotes.title: Cultural Preservation
culturalNotes.content: While many traditions are fading, there is a strong movement to preserve Yoruba culture. Festivals, language schools, and family teachings help keep traditions alive.

culturalNotes.title: Respect for Elders
culturalNotes.content: One tradition that remains strong is respect for elders. Prostrating (for men) and kneeling (for women) are still practiced in many homes and ceremonies.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'ṣáájú' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'ṣáájú' refers to a previous time.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'tradition has changed'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'ti yí pa' means 'has changed'.

practiceExercises.question: What is the opposite of 'àtijọ́'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Òde-òní' means modern times.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'bàbá ńlá' refer to?
practiceExercises.explanation: It means forefathers/ancestors.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Now, things have changed'?
practiceExercises.explanation: That correctly expresses present change.

tips: Share stories of 'ṣáájú' with your children to pass down traditions.
Ask your elders about 'àtijọ́' – they love to share.
Understanding cultural changes helps in cross‑generational business.
Discuss traditions with your spouse and decide which to keep.
If you're new, learning about 'ṣáájú' vs 'nísìnyí' helps you understand the culture.
Listen to elders' stories to learn about past traditions.
Use contrast to explain your own cultural background.

levels.title: Level 47: Phone
levels.description: Bad networks: 'Hello, can you hear me?' 'Cut the call and call me back,' 'I am on the line.'

vocabulary.example: Hello? ẹ̀ ń kí?
vocabulary.culturalNote: English 'hello' is commonly used, often followed by Yoruba.

vocabulary.example: Ṣé o gbọ́ mi? Nẹ́tíwọọkì kò dára.

vocabulary.word: Kọ́ kọ́lì, kí o sì tún pè mí
vocabulary.translation: Cut the call and call me back
vocabulary.pronunciation: koh koh-lee, kee oh shee too-n peh mee
vocabulary.example: Kọ́ kọ́lì, kí o sì tún pè mí, nẹ́tíwọọkì ń ṣòro.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Common request when network is poor.

vocabulary.translation: I am on the phone / on the line
vocabulary.example: Mo wà lórí ẹ̀rọ, màá pe ọ́ lẹ́yìn náà.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Can also mean 'I am on the device'.

vocabulary.example: Nẹ́tíwọọkì kò dára lónìí.
Ó kú lẹ́yìn ìṣẹ́jú díẹ̀.
Túndún pè mí nígbà tí nẹ́tíwọọkì bá dára.
Kí ni nọ́ḿbà rẹ, kí n lè pè ọ́.
Mo máa fi ọ́ sílẹ̀, ó dàbọ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Polite way to end a call.

vocabulary.example: Ṣé o lè fífi sọ́ǹ sí mi, kò sí nẹ́tíwọọkì.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Asking for SMS instead of call.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'jọ̀wọ́' and conditional phrases to make polite requests on the phone.
examples: Jọ̀wọ́, túndún pè mí – Please call me again.
Bí o bá lè, fífi sọ́ǹ sí mi – If you can, text me.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'kú' (die) to describe a dropped call or dead network.
examples: Ó kú lórí ẹ̀rọ – The call dropped.
Nẹ́tíwọọkì kú – The network died.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Hello? Adé ló ń pè.
dialogue.translation: Hello? It's Ade calling.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Bísí ni. Báwo ni? Ṣé o gbọ́ mi?
dialogue.translation: It's Bisi. How are you? Can you hear me?

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Kò yé mi, nẹ́tíwọọkì kò dára. Jọ̀wọ́, túndún pè mí.
dialogue.translation: I can't hear you, the network is bad. Please call me again.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Ó dára, màá kọ́ kọ́lì, kí n sì tún pè ọ́.
dialogue.translation: Okay, I'll cut the call and call you back.

dialogue.speaker: Adé
dialogue.text: Ẹ ṣé. Ó dàbọ̀ fún ìṣẹ́jú kan.
dialogue.translation: Thank you. Goodbye for a minute.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Ó dàbọ̀.
dialogue.translation: Goodbye.

culturalNotes.title: Phone Etiquette
culturalNotes.content: In Nigeria, it's common to greet the person before stating your name, even if they have caller ID. 'Hello, Adé ló ń pè' (Hello, it's Ade calling) is polite.

culturalNotes.title: Network Issues
culturalNotes.content: Network problems are common. People are used to calls dropping and often say 'Ó kú' (it died) without frustration.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'Can you hear me?'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Gbọ́' means to hear.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'kọ́ kọ́lì, kí o sì tún pè mí' mean?
options: Cut the call and call me back
practiceExercises.explanation: It's a request to redial.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'the call dropped'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ó kú' is used for dropped calls.

practiceExercises.question: What is a polite way to end a phone call?
options: Ma á pè ọ́ lẹ́yìn náà
practiceExercises.explanation: All are appropriate ways to end a call.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask for someone's phone number?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Nọ́ḿbà' means number.

tips: Teach children how to answer the phone politely in Yoruba.
If you have bad network, use these phrases to manage calls.
In business calls, network issues happen – use these phrases professionally.
When your spouse calls and the line is bad, these phrases help.
Expect network issues; these phrases will be your lifeline.
Always identify yourself first when calling.
If the network is bad, speak slowly and clearly.

levels.title: Level 48: Opinion
levels.description: Stating views without starting a fight: 'In my opinion,' 'I beg to differ.'

vocabulary.translation: In my opinion / As for me
vocabulary.example: Ní tèmi, kò dára tó.
Mo rò pé ó yẹ ká ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Common way to introduce an opinion.

vocabulary.example: Ó ṣeé ṣe kí ó ṣàṣìṣe.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Polite way to suggest an alternative.

vocabulary.example: Mo gbà pé ó sọ òótọ́.
Mo yàtọ̀ pẹ̀lú ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ.
Pẹ̀lú ọ̀wọ̀, mo rò pé o ṣàṣìṣe.

vocabulary.translation: Don't you see it as? / Don't you think?
vocabulary.example: Ǹjẹ́ o rí i bí ó ṣe dára tó?

vocabulary.word: Kò yẹ kí á gbàgbé pé
vocabulary.pronunciation: koh yeh kee ah gbah-gbeh peh
vocabulary.example: Kò yẹ kí á gbàgbé pé ó ṣe pàtàkì.

vocabulary.translation: In my eyes / From my perspective
vocabulary.example: Lójú mi, ó dára.
Bó ṣe wù, ká máa bá a lọ.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use phrases like 'pẹ̀lú ọ̀wọ̀' (with respect) or 'mo rò pé' (I think) before disagreeing.
examples: Pẹ̀lú ọ̀wọ̀, mo rò pé o yẹ ká wo òye mìíràn.
Mo rò pé ó ṣeé ṣe kí ó ṣàṣìṣe.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'mo gbà pé' (I agree that) to show agreement.
examples: Mo gbà pé ó sọ òótọ́.
Mo gbà pẹ̀lú rẹ – I agree with you.

dialogue.speaker: Kúnlé
dialogue.text: Mo rò pé ó yẹ ká lo owó yìí fún iṣẹ́ tuntun.
dialogue.translation: I think we should use this money for a new project.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Ní tèmi, ó dára ká kọ́kọ́ san gbèsè.
dialogue.translation: In my opinion, it's better to pay off debts first.

dialogue.speaker: Kúnlé
dialogue.text: Mo gbọ́ ohun tó o ń sọ, ṣùgbọ́n pẹ̀lú ọ̀wọ̀, mo rò pé ìdókòwó yìí máa ràn wá lọ́wọ́.
dialogue.translation: I hear what you're saying, but with respect, I think this investment will help us.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Ó ṣeé ṣe kí o jẹ́ òótọ́. Ká wá ọ̀nà àárín?
dialogue.translation: Maybe you're right. Shall we find a middle way?

dialogue.speaker: Kúnlé
dialogue.text: Mo gbà pẹ̀lú ọ́. Ká fi ìdajì ṣe iṣẹ́, ká fi ìdajì san gbèsè.
dialogue.translation: I agree with you. Let's use half for work, half to pay debt.

dialogue.speaker: Bísí
dialogue.text: Ó dára. Bó ṣe wù, ká ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.
dialogue.translation: Okay. Whatever, let's do that.

culturalNotes.title: Polite Disagreement
culturalNotes.content: In Yoruba culture, direct disagreement can be seen as confrontational. It's important to use softening phrases and acknowledge the other person's point before stating your own.

culturalNotes.title: Saving Face
culturalNotes.content: Allowing the other person to 'save face' by not directly saying they are wrong is crucial. Phrases like 'Ó ṣeé ṣe kí o jẹ́ òótọ́' (maybe you're right) help.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'In my opinion' politely?
practiceExercises.explanation: All are common ways to introduce an opinion.

practiceExercises.question: What is a polite way to disagree?
options: Pẹ̀lú ọ̀wọ̀, mo rò pé o yàtọ̀.
practiceExercises.explanation: It starts with respect and states difference.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'mo gbà pé' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo gbà' means 'I agree'.

practiceExercises.question: How do you soften a disagreement?
practiceExercises.explanation: All are softening techniques.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'bó ṣe wù' imply?
practiceExercises.explanation: It's used to end a debate amicably.

tips: Teach children to express opinions respectfully at home.
In group discussions, use these phrases to be heard without offending.
In meetings, polite disagreement can lead to better decisions.
Disagreeing with your spouse? Use 'pẹ̀lú ọ̀wọ̀' – it works.
When discussing with elders, always soften your opinion.
Listen first, then respond politely.
Use 'mo rò pé' to start any opinion.

levels.title: Level 49: Story
levels.description: Narrative structure: setting, problem, climax, resolution. 'Let me tell you what happened...'
learningObjectives: Tell a simple story with a clear structure
Use narrative markers like 'ní ọjọ́ kan' (one day)

vocabulary.word: Jẹ́ kí n sọ ìtàn kan fún yín
vocabulary.translation: Let me tell you all a story
vocabulary.pronunciation: jeh kee n soh ee-tahn kahn foon yin
vocabulary.example: Jẹ́ kí n sọ ìtàn kan fún yín nípa ọjọ́ ìsinmi mi.
Ní ọjọ́ kan, mo lọ sí ọjà.
Lóòótọ́ lọ́nà, àwọn ẹranko ń bọ̀.
Ìṣòro bẹ̀rẹ̀ nígbà tí...
Ìparí ìtàn ni pé...
Lẹ́yìn náà, mo lọ sí ilé.
Nígbà tí mo débẹ̀, nǹkan ti yí.
Ó ṣẹlẹ̀ pé kò sí ẹnìkan níbẹ̀.
Nítorí náà, mo pinnu láti lọ.

vocabulary.translation: The story is full of lessons
vocabulary.example: Ìtàn náà kún fún ẹ̀kọ́ tó ṣe pàtàkì.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use time markers like 'ní ọjọ́ kan' (one day), 'lẹ́yìn náà' (after that), 'nígbà tí' (when) to sequence events.
examples: Ní ọjọ́ kan, mo lọ sí ọjà. Lẹ́yìn náà, mo pàdé ọ̀rẹ́ mi.
Nígbà tí mo débẹ̀, ó ti lọ.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'ìtàn náà kọ́ wa pé' (the story teaches us that) to introduce the lesson.
examples: Ìtàn náà kọ́ wa pé ká máa ṣe rere.
Ẹ̀kọ́ tí a rí kọ́ ni pé...
grammarPoints.pattern: Ìtàn náà kọ́ wa pé + moral

dialogue.speaker: Bàbá (Father)
dialogue.text: Ẹ jọ́kòó, ẹ jẹ́ kí n sọ ìtàn kan fún yín.
dialogue.translation: Sit down, let me tell you all a story.

dialogue.speaker: Àwọn ọmọ (Children)
dialogue.text: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, bàbá! Sọ ọ́ fún wa.
dialogue.translation: Yes, father! Tell us.

dialogue.speaker: Bàbá
dialogue.text: Ní ọjọ́ kan, ọkùnrin kan ń lọ sí ọjà. Lójú ọ̀nà, ó pàdé ajá kan tí ń sọ̀rọ̀!
dialogue.translation: One day, a man was going to the market. On the way, he met a dog that was talking!

dialogue.speaker: Ọmọ
dialogue.text: Ajá ń sọ̀rọ̀? Kí ló ṣẹlẹ̀ lẹ́yìn náà?
dialogue.translation: A dog talking? What happened after that?

dialogue.speaker: Bàbá
dialogue.text: Ajá náà ní kí ọkùnrin náà tọ̀ ọ́ lọ. Nígbà tí wọ́n débẹ̀, wọ́n rí àpótí owó!
dialogue.translation: The dog asked the man to follow him. When they got there, they found a box of money!

dialogue.speaker: Ọmọ
dialogue.text: Wàhálà! Kí ni wọ́n ṣe pẹ̀lú rẹ̀?
dialogue.translation: Wow! What did they do with it?

dialogue.speaker: Bàbá
dialogue.text: Wọ́n pín in. Ìtàn náà kọ́ wa pé ká máa ṣeun sí àwọn ẹlòmíì, torí a kì í mọ ohun tí ọ̀la ń fún wa.
dialogue.translation: They shared it. The story teaches us to be kind to others, because we don't know what tomorrow will bring.

culturalNotes.title: Storytelling Tradition
culturalNotes.content: Yoruba storytelling (itàn) is an oral tradition. Elders tell stories to entertain and teach moral lessons. Children gather around, especially in the evening, to listen.

culturalNotes.title: Engaging the Audience
culturalNotes.content: Storytellers often engage listeners by asking questions like 'Kí ló ṣẹlẹ̀ lẹ́yìn náà?' (What happened next?) to keep them involved.

practiceExercises.question: How do you start a story with 'One day'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ní ọjọ́ kan' is the common opener.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'lẹ́yìn náà' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It means 'after that' or 'then'.

practiceExercises.question: How do you introduce the moral of a story?
practiceExercises.explanation: That's how you state the lesson.

practiceExercises.question: What is the climax of a story?
practiceExercises.explanation: The climax is the peak of the problem.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Let me tell you a story'?
options: Jẹ́ kí n sọ ìtàn kan fún yín
practiceExercises.explanation: That's the correct opening.

levels.title: Test 5
levels.description: Final Assessment: Full, unstructured conversation – meet a stranger at an event, introduce yourself, discuss where you’re from, current affairs, family, joke, and exchange contact info seamlessly.
learningObjectives: Integrate vocabulary and grammar from all levels

practiceExercises.question: You meet a stranger at a wedding. How do you greet them politely?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ẹ kú iṣẹ́ ibi ayẹyẹ' (well done on the event work) is a polite, context‑specific greeting.

practiceExercises.question: They ask where you're from. You are from Ibadan. What do you say?
practiceExercises.explanation: All are acceptable ways to state origin/residence.

practiceExercises.question: They ask about your family. How do you say 'I have two children'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo ní ọmọ méjì' is correct.

practiceExercises.question: The conversation turns to current affairs (e.g., election). You want to state your opinion politely. How do you start?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mo rò pé' is a polite way to introduce an opinion.

practiceExercises.question: You want to make a joke about the weather. What could you say?
options: Ó gbóná lónìí, àbí? Ẹ̀rù máa jẹ mí pé oòrùn á yọ́ wa!
practiceExercises.explanation: That's a light‑hearted joke about the heat.

practiceExercises.question: The stranger says something you disagree with. How do you disagree politely?
options: Pẹ̀lú ọ̀wọ̀, mo rò pé ó yàtọ̀
practiceExercises.explanation: That's a polite disagreement.

practiceExercises.question: You want to exchange contact information. How do you ask for their phone number?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kí ni nọ́ḿbà rẹ?' asks for the number.

practiceExercises.question: They give you their number. How do you say you'll call them?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Màá pe ọ́' is future: 'I will call you'.

practiceExercises.question: The event is ending. How do you say goodbye?
practiceExercises.explanation: All are polite farewells.

practiceExercises.question: As you leave, you want to say 'It was nice meeting you.' How do you say that?
options: Inú mi dùn láti pàdé rẹ
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Inú mi dùn láti pàdé rẹ' expresses happiness at meeting.
